Seneca mission: The Seneca Mission, established in 1821 in present-day Oklahoma, was a significant effort to relocate the Seneca people from their traditional lands in New York. Led by missionary Isaac McCoy, the mission aimed to integrate the Seneca into American society through education, agriculture, and Christian beliefs. The mission faced challenges including disease, cultural clashes, and the loss of traditional ways. While the Seneca Mission ultimately failed to achieve its goals, it played a crucial role in the forced relocation of the Seneca people and reflected the broader policies of westward expansion during the 19th century.
Colliers (company): Colliers International Group Inc., formerly known simply as Colliers, is a global commercial real estate services and investment company headquartered in Toronto, Canada. Founded in 1925 by Harold F. Colliers, the company initially focused on brokerage services in the Canadian market. Over time, it expanded its operations to encompass a wider range of services, including property management, investment sales, and appraisal.  Colliers has grown significantly through acquisitions, becoming one of the largest real estate service providers globally, with a network spanning over 60 countries. The company's success is attributed to its diversified services, global reach, and expertise across various real estate sectors.
Beverly Wilshire Hotel: The Beverly Wilshire Hotel, a landmark in Beverly Hills, California, is a luxury hotel renowned for its elegant design, luxurious accommodations, and prominent location on Wilshire Boulevard. Opened in 1928, the hotel originally served as a grand residential complex but was transformed into a hotel in 1954. It has been featured in numerous films, including "Pretty Woman" and "Beverly Hills Cop," solidifying its status as a symbol of Hollywood glamour and extravagance. The hotel has hosted numerous celebrities and dignitaries, showcasing its reputation as a premier destination for discerning travelers.
Kinky Boots (film): "Kinky Boots" (2005) is a British comedy-drama film directed by Julian Jarrold, based on the 2005 documentary "Kinky Boots" by Geoff Deane. The film tells the story of Charlie Price, a young man who inherits his family's struggling shoe factory in Northampton, England. Charlie finds an unexpected business opportunity in Lola, a drag queen who needs custom-made boots. The film explores themes of acceptance, friendship, and self-discovery, as Charlie and Lola work together to revitalize the factory and challenge traditional notions of masculinity. Notably, the film features a memorable performance by Chiwetel Ejiofor as Lola, and received critical acclaim for its heartwarming story and vibrant visuals.
Luis Milla (footballer, born 1966): Luis Milla (born 1966) is a Spanish former professional footballer who played as a midfielder. He was a key player for the Spain national team, earning 67 caps and playing in two FIFA World Cups (1990 and 1994). Milla, known for his technical skills and passing ability, played for several prominent clubs, including Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid. His career highlights include winning two La Liga titles and a Copa del Rey with Real Madrid. He also played in the 1986 and 1988 European Championships. Following his retirement, Milla transitioned into coaching, managing several clubs in Spain and South Korea.
Master Z: Ip Man Legacy: "Master Z: Ip Man Legacy" is a 2018 Hong Kong martial arts film directed by Yuen Woo-ping, known for his work on films like "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and "The Matrix." The film serves as a spin-off to the "Ip Man" series, focusing on the character of Cheung Tin-chi, played by Zhang Jin, who was introduced as a rival of Ip Man in the second film. The film depicts Cheung's journey after his defeat at the hands of Ip Man, as he seeks redemption and confronts new challenges in the turbulent post-war Hong Kong of the 1950s. With elaborate fight choreography by Yuen Woo-ping and a star-studded cast including Dave Bautista and Michelle Yeoh, "Master Z" showcases the action-packed and visually impressive style of Hong Kong martial arts cinema.
Warren W. Tolman: Warren W. Tolman (1892–1959) was an American psychologist known for his significant contributions to the field of learning theory. He is particularly remembered for his research on latent learning, which demonstrated that learning can occur without immediate reinforcement. Tolman's studies on rats navigating mazes, conducted in the 1930s, showed that animals could develop cognitive maps of their environment, even without being rewarded for their actions. These findings challenged the prevailing behaviorist view that learning was solely dependent on stimulus-response associations, and helped pave the way for the development of cognitive psychology. Tolman was also a pioneer in the use of mathematical models to describe learning processes, and his work continues to influence researchers today.
Prajakta Koli: Prajakta Koli, known online as "MostlySane," is an Indian YouTuber, actress, and social media influencer. She began her YouTube career in 2015, quickly gaining popularity for her comedic sketches, relatable vlogs, and positive messages. Koli's channel has amassed over 7 million subscribers, making her one of the most popular Indian YouTubers. She has also ventured into acting, appearing in the Hindi-language web series "Mismatched" (2020) and "Jug Jugg Jeeyo" (2022). Beyond YouTube, Koli is an advocate for mental health awareness and uses her platform to promote social causes.
Abdul Karim Khan: Abdul Karim Khan (1872–1937) was a renowned Indian classical musician and vocalist, considered one of the pioneers of the Gwalior Gharana style. Born in a musical family in Gwalior, he received his initial training from his father, and later from renowned maestros like Ustad Allauddin Khan. Known for his powerful voice and unique vocal techniques, Khan's contributions to Hindustani music are significant, particularly his development of the "khayal" form. He was highly influential in the revival and popularization of classical music in India during the early 20th century, inspiring generations of musicians. His legacy continues to be celebrated through his recordings and the numerous musicians who have learned from him.
Tegernsee (lake): Tegernsee is a lake in the Bavarian Alps of southern Germany, located near the town of Tegernsee. It is the third-largest lake in Bavaria, covering an area of approximately 9.3 square kilometers. Known for its scenic beauty, Tegernsee has been a popular destination for recreation and tourism since the 19th century, with its shores featuring numerous resorts, hotels, and hiking trails. The lake was formed by glaciers during the last ice age, and its waters are remarkably clear due to the lack of pollution.  The nearby Tegernsee Monastery, founded in 746, has played a significant role in the region's history and continues to be an important cultural and historical landmark.
SSD Casarano Calcio: SSD Casarano Calcio, founded in 2005 as Associazione Sportiva Dilettantistica Casarano Calcio, is an Italian professional football club based in Casarano, Puglia. The team's history can be traced back to the 1920s with earlier iterations under different names. Casarano's most notable period came during the 1980s and 1990s when they spent several seasons in Serie C1, the third tier of Italian football. After years of financial difficulties and multiple name changes, the club was reborn as SSD Casarano Calcio in 2018 and now competes in the Serie D, the fourth tier of Italian football.
Max Payne (video game): "Max Payne" is a 2001 third-person shooter video game developed by Remedy Entertainment and published by Rockstar Games. The game follows Max Payne, a former NYPD detective seeking revenge for the murder of his wife and child. It introduced a unique "bullet time" mechanic, allowing players to slow down time during combat, enhancing the gameplay's action-oriented experience. The game's noir-inspired atmosphere and gritty storytelling, along with its innovative gameplay features, were critical and commercial successes, earning numerous awards and solidifying its place as a landmark in the video game industry.
Songs from Wasties Orchard: "Songs from Wasties Orchard" is a 2000 album by the alternative rock band, Pavement. Released on Matador Records, it marked the band's fourth studio album and featured a shift towards a more polished sound. The album's title, inspired by a childhood memory of singer Stephen Malkmus, alludes to the band's origins in the Pacific Northwest. The album is considered a highlight in Pavement's discography, showcasing the band's signature blend of experimental rock, lo-fi aesthetics, and witty lyrics.  It produced notable singles like "Spit on a Stranger" and "The Hexx," cementing Pavement's influence on indie rock music during the 1990s.
Ionas Nicolaou: Ionas Nicolaou (born 1946) is a Greek-American chemist renowned for his groundbreaking work in organic synthesis.  He is best known for his development of innovative methods for synthesizing complex natural products, including the anticancer drug Taxol. Nicolaou's career spans decades, marked by numerous publications, awards, and collaborations. He has held academic positions at the University of Pennsylvania and the Scripps Research Institute, where he established a prominent research group. Nicolaou's contributions have significantly advanced the field of organic chemistry, particularly in the areas of natural product synthesis and drug discovery.
Econoline Crush: "Econoline Crush" was a Canadian rock band formed in 1992 in Toronto, Ontario. They are known for their energetic live shows, blend of hard rock and punk, and their use of politically charged lyrics. The band gained notoriety in the 1990s with their hit singles "The Real" and "Get Up." They released four studio albums before disbanding in 2002, and have reunited for occasional tours and performances since then. Notable members include Greg Keelor (vocals, guitar), Andy Curran (bass), and Dave Clark (drums).
Second Chance (2016 TV series): "Second Chance" is an American science fiction drama television series that aired on Fox from January 13 to May 11, 2016. Created by David Wiener, the series follows the story of Jimmy Pritchard, a retired police officer who is killed in the line of duty but is brought back to life by a mysterious organization as a younger, healthier clone. The series explores themes of second chances, morality, and the nature of identity, as Jimmy struggles to reconcile his past life with his new reality. It starred Rob Kazinsky as Jimmy, along with Dilshad Vadsaria, Adhir Kalyan, and Tim DeKay. Despite positive reviews for its premise and characters, the show was canceled after one season due to low viewership.
Greece at the 1990 European Athletics Ch: Greece participated in the 1990 European Athletics Championships held in Split, Yugoslavia, from August 26 to September 2, 1990.  The Greek team achieved a notable performance, securing two bronze medals: one in the women's 400m hurdles by Paraskevi Patoulidou and the other in the men's 100m by Angelos Pavlakakis.  Greece also had several other strong performances, including fourth-place finishes in the men's 4x100m relay and the women's 4x400m relay. The team's success at the championships contributed to the ongoing development of Greek athletics in the late 20th century.
The Bends (album): "The Bends" is the second studio album by the English alternative rock band Radiohead, released in March 1995. It was produced by the band and John Leckie, and was recorded in various locations, including London and Oxford. The album marked a significant shift in the band's sound, moving away from the experimental and atmospheric style of their debut "Pablo Honey" towards a more polished and commercially accessible direction. The album achieved massive success, reaching number one in the UK and spawning several hit singles, including "My Iron Lung," "High and Dry / Planet Telex," and "Fake Plastic Trees." "The Bends" is widely considered a landmark album in 1990s alternative rock and cemented Radiohead's status as one of the leading bands of the decade.
TRPM8: TRPM8, short for "transient receptor potential melastatin 8," is a protein that acts as a receptor for cold temperatures and certain chemical compounds, such as menthol. Located in the cell membranes of sensory neurons, TRPM8 activation triggers a signal that is transmitted to the brain, ultimately resulting in the sensation of cold. This receptor plays a crucial role in thermoregulation, contributing to the body's ability to sense and respond to changes in temperature. Identified in 2002 by a team led by David Julius at the University of California, San Francisco, TRPM8 has become a key focus of research into pain perception and the development of novel analgesics.
Francesco Reda: Francesco Reda (born 1981) is a German-Italian politician and digital rights activist. He served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the Pirate Party from 2014 to 2019. Reda is known for his advocacy for digital freedoms and his work on issues such as data privacy, copyright reform, and net neutrality. He played a significant role in the development of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a landmark European law that aims to protect the personal data of individuals. Reda has also been a vocal critic of surveillance practices and censorship. His work has contributed to raising awareness about the importance of digital rights and their impact on society.
Take a Look Over Your Shoulder: "Take a Look Over Your Shoulder" is a popular song written and originally performed by the American country music singer, Gene Watson, in 1979. The song reached number one on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart and became one of Watson's signature hits. Known for its catchy melody and relatable lyrics about the anxieties of love and relationships, "Take a Look Over Your Shoulder" has been covered by numerous artists over the years, further solidifying its status as a country music classic. Its popularity also led to its inclusion in various films and television shows, contributing to its lasting impact on popular culture.
Dyle et Bacalan DB-70: The Dyle et Bacalan DB-70 was a French single-seat, single-engined fighter aircraft designed and manufactured by Dyle et Bacalan during the 1930s. Developed in response to a 1933 French Air Ministry requirement for a new fighter, the DB-70 was notable for its innovative design features, including a cantilever monoplane wing and retractable landing gear. Despite promising performance in testing, the DB-70 was ultimately rejected in favor of the Dewoitine D.520. Although it never entered production, the DB-70 remains a significant example of French aircraft design in the interwar period and its development influenced subsequent French fighter projects.
Schmidt-Lademann House: The Schmidt-Lademann House is a historic residence located in the city of Davenport, Iowa, United States. Constructed in 1857, the house is an excellent example of Greek Revival architecture, with its distinctive features including a two-story structure with a central portico supported by four fluted columns. The home was built by German immigrant Henry Schmidt, a successful local businessman, and remained in his family's possession until 1971. Today, the Schmidt-Lademann House is recognized as a contributing property to the Davenport Historic District and serves as a reminder of the city's rich architectural heritage.
Rosette (design): The rosette, a decorative motif featuring a circular arrangement of petals or lobes, has a long and diverse history. Found in numerous cultures across the globe, rosettes have adorned everything from ancient Egyptian tombs to medieval manuscripts. They often symbolize the sun, a flower, or a spiritual concept, with their design varying significantly depending on the cultural context. Notable examples include the rosettes found in Islamic architecture, where they are frequently used in intricate tilework, and the rosette motifs featured in Renaissance art, often used to adorn clothing and architectural elements. The rosette's versatility and enduring appeal have ensured its continued use in design across various artistic disciplines and mediums.
Elizabeth Cary, Viscountess Falkland: Elizabeth Cary, Viscountess Falkland (1585-1639), was an English writer and philosopher who lived during the early modern period. Known for her sharp intellect and challenging ideas, she was a prominent figure in the literary circles of her time. Cary's most notable work, "The Tragedy of Mariam, the Fair Queen of Jewry," was a historical play published in 1613, highlighting her interest in classical literature and themes of political power.  She was also known for her philosophical writings, which explored questions of faith, reason, and morality. Cary's works provide valuable insights into the intellectual and social landscape of early modern England, making her a significant figure in literary and philosophical history.
Denis Lawson (footballer): Denis Lawson (born 26 July 1957) is a Scottish former professional footballer who played as a striker.  He began his career with Dundee United in 1974, quickly rising to prominence for his prolific goal scoring and winning the Scottish League Cup in 1979. He enjoyed a successful career across multiple teams, including stints at Norwich City, Leicester City, and Ayr United, before ending his playing career with Montrose in 1991. Lawson was also a key player for the Scotland national team, earning 18 caps and scoring 6 goals, including a memorable goal against England at Wembley Stadium in 1985. He is remembered as a skillful and powerful striker who contributed significantly to both club and national team success throughout his career.
Job E. Hedges: Job E. Hedges (1859-1922) was an American businessman and pioneer in the field of advertising. He is best known for founding the advertising agency Hedges, Jenkins & Co. in 1894, later renamed Hedges, Jenkins & Co. and ultimately becoming part of the J. Walter Thompson Company. Known for his innovative approach to advertising, Hedges advocated for using "reason-why" advertising, emphasizing logical arguments and persuasive storytelling to influence consumers. He also played a crucial role in the development of early advertising research techniques, contributing to the professionalization of the field. His legacy lives on through the impact of his pioneering work and the lasting influence of his agency on the advertising landscape.
Santo Ni\u00f1o Church (Tacloban): The Santo Niño Church, officially known as the **Minor Basilica of the Santo Niño**, is a Roman Catholic church located in Tacloban City, Leyte, Philippines. Built in 1956, the church is notable for its striking neo-Gothic architectural style and is dedicated to the Santo Niño de Cebú, a venerated image of the Child Jesus.  The church was severely damaged by Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda) in 2013, but it was subsequently rebuilt and reopened in 2016. The Santo Niño Church is a significant religious landmark in Tacloban, attracting numerous devotees and tourists alike.
French submarine Fulton: The French submarine *Fulton* was a  *Plongeur*-class submarine built in 1888 for the French Navy. This vessel was the first true submarine to be built by France and the first to be armed with a torpedo.  Named after the American inventor Robert Fulton, the submarine was a significant technological advancement, utilizing compressed air for propulsion and a single torpedo tube. While the *Fulton* only had a limited range and speed, it served as a crucial stepping stone for the development of submarine technology in France. The submarine was decommissioned in 1899 and ultimately scrapped in 1902.
Osbornoceros: *Osbornoceros* is an extinct genus of prehistoric ruminant mammal that lived in North America during the late Miocene epoch, approximately 10-5 million years ago.  This four-legged herbivore was characterized by its large size, reaching up to 2.5 meters in length, and distinctive antlers, which were long and branched.  The genus was named after the renowned paleontologist Henry Fairfield Osborn, who first described the species *Osbornoceros osborni* in 1929.  *Osbornoceros* is classified as a member of the family Antilocapridae, which today is represented by the sole surviving species, the pronghorn.
Adrian Lis: Adrian Lis is a prominent figure in the field of [insert field of expertise], known for his groundbreaking work on [insert key area of research/contribution]. Born in [insert place of birth] in [insert year of birth], Lis received his [insert highest degree] from [insert university] in [insert year of graduation]. His career has been marked by significant achievements, including [insert specific achievements, e.g., publishing influential books, founding research institutes, leading innovative projects]. Lis's work has had a lasting impact on [insert specific impact, e.g., shaping the field, advancing technology, addressing societal issues], and his contributions continue to be recognized and celebrated by his peers.
S\u00fcd Autobahn: The Süd Autobahn (South Autobahn), also known as the A1, is a major freeway in Austria, stretching from Vienna in the east to Salzburg in the west. Opened in sections between 1967 and 1973, the A1 is a vital link for both domestic and international traffic, connecting the Austrian capital to the country's western regions and neighboring Germany. It traverses the landscape of the Vienna Basin and the Eastern Alps, featuring tunnels like the Tauerntunnel and the Bosruck Tunnel, which significantly reduce travel time across mountainous terrain. The A1 is a key element of Austria's motorway network, facilitating trade, tourism, and regional connectivity.
David Corrente: David Corrente is a prominent figure in the field of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning, known for his contributions to research and development in the area of natural language processing (NLP). He is the founder and CEO of Corrente, a company specializing in AI-driven solutions for various industries, including finance, healthcare, and education. Corrente holds a PhD in Computer Science from Stanford University and has published numerous academic papers and patents in the field of NLP. Notably, he played a key role in developing the Corrente NLP Engine, a powerful tool for understanding and processing human language, which has been adopted by several major corporations.
Belluscone: A Sicilian Story: "Belluscone: A Sicilian Story" is a 2009 novel by Italian author Andrea Camilleri, featuring the popular fictional detective Salvo Montalbano. Set in the fictional town of Vigata, based on the real-life town of Porto Empedocle in Sicily, the novel follows Montalbano as he investigates the murder of a prominent local figure, Don Calogero Belluscone. The story explores themes of Sicilian tradition, family secrets, and the pervasive presence of the Mafia in the region.  Camilleri weaves in vivid descriptions of Sicilian life, culture, and landscape, creating a compelling and authentic atmosphere.
Jon Coghill: Jon Coghill (born 1967) is a British author and journalist known for his work in the field of alternative medicine. He is the founder of the website "The Alternative Doctor," which provides information and resources on holistic health practices. Coghill is a vocal advocate for natural therapies, particularly those involving herbal remedies and nutrition. He has authored several books on the subject, including "The Complete Guide to Natural Healing" and "The Healing Power of Food." Coghill's work has been both praised for its accessibility and criticized for its lack of scientific rigor, sparking debate within the medical community.
Soundtrack for a Revolution: "Soundtrack for a Revolution" refers to a compilation album released in 2007 that features songs of protest and revolution from around the world. The album, curated by filmmaker and activist Michael Franti, aims to raise awareness and support for various social justice movements. It showcases a diverse array of artists, including legendary figures like Bob Dylan and Nina Simone alongside newer artists like Manu Chao and The Coup. The album gained recognition for its powerful message of resistance and its ability to connect disparate musical styles while promoting a sense of global solidarity.
Seligenstadt: Seligenstadt is a town in the district of Offenbach, in the state of Hesse, Germany. Located on the Main River, the town is notable for its historical significance, particularly its Benedictine abbey founded in 742 by Saint Boniface. Seligenstadt's historic center is well-preserved, featuring the impressive Michaelskirche, one of the oldest and most significant Romanesque churches in Germany. The town also boasts a rich cultural heritage, hosting an annual medieval festival and featuring a museum showcasing local history and art. Today, Seligenstadt attracts visitors seeking a blend of historical charm and modern amenities.
Deep lateral femoral notch sign: The Deep Lateral Femoral Notch Sign (DLFNS) is a radiographic finding used to diagnose anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears. It was first described in 1988 by Dr. D. Jackson and colleagues and is characterized by a deep notch or indentation on the lateral aspect of the distal femur. This sign is considered highly specific for ACL tears, though its sensitivity can vary depending on the severity and location of the tear. The DLFNS is a valuable tool for radiologists and orthopedic surgeons in assessing potential ACL injuries and guiding treatment decisions.
Clapton (1973 album): "Clapton" is Eric Clapton's fourth solo album, released in 1973. It marks a significant shift in Clapton's career, showcasing his embrace of a more blues-oriented sound after his departure from Derek and the Dominos. The album features several blues classics like "Let It Rain" and "Motherless Children," along with original tracks penned by Clapton and his collaborators. Notably, it includes the single "I Shot the Sheriff," originally by Bob Marley and the Wailers, which became a global hit and further established Clapton's standing as a blues-rock icon. "Clapton" was a commercial success, reaching the top 10 in the US and UK, solidifying his solo career after years of successful collaborations.
The Alaskans: "The Alaskans" is a 1959 American television series that aired on ABC, starring  Roger Moore as the head of a group of young men working for a large oil company in the Alaskan wilderness. Created by Ivan Goff and Ben Roberts, known for their work on "The Untouchables," the series aimed to capture the adventurous spirit and challenges of early oil exploration in Alaska. While the series lasted only one season, it showcased the rugged terrain, harsh weather, and unique challenges of working in the Alaskan wilderness, offering audiences a glimpse into a frontier setting. The show also featured prominent guest stars, including future stars like James Coburn and Robert Redford, contributing to its popularity.
Detroit City Is the Place to Be: "Detroit City Is the Place to Be" is a popular slogan used to promote the city of Detroit, Michigan.  The slogan, which gained prominence in the 1960s, reflected a period of optimism and growth in the city, known as "Motor City," as it was a major center for the American automotive industry.  While the city experienced economic challenges in subsequent decades, the slogan has been revived in recent years as Detroit has seen a resurgence in its cultural and creative sectors.  The slogan, often associated with Motown music and the city's vibrant cultural scene, serves as a reminder of Detroit's enduring spirit and potential.
Feldmoching-Hasenbergl: Feldmoching-Hasenbergl is a district in the north of Munich, Germany.  The district is primarily a residential area, with a mix of single-family homes and apartment buildings. It was incorporated into Munich in 1938. The district has a population of around 50,000 people. Notable features of the district include the Feldmoching train station, a major hub for public transportation, and the Hasenbergl, a hill offering scenic views of the city.
Systemd-boot: Systemd-boot is a boot manager for the Linux operating system, designed to replace traditional boot loaders like GRUB. It is part of the systemd suite of system utilities, offering a streamlined and faster booting process. Systemd-boot utilizes an EFI (Extensible Firmware Interface) boot environment, directly loading the Linux kernel without relying on a separate boot loader. Its key features include automatic detection and mounting of file systems, simplified configuration, and support for secure boot. Systemd-boot was first introduced in 2013 and has since gained popularity due to its ease of use and performance advantages, particularly in modern UEFI-based systems.
USNS Sgt. Andrew Miller: USNS *Sgt. Andrew Miller* (T-AK-3017) is a United States Navy auxiliary ship, named after Sergeant Andrew Miller who was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor for his actions in the Vietnam War. The ship, a Lewis and Clark-class cargo ship, was built by National Steel and Shipbuilding Company and commissioned into the Military Sealift Command in 1998. *Sgt. Andrew Miller* is designed to transport cargo, including military equipment and supplies, and has participated in numerous humanitarian missions and disaster relief efforts, including the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and Hurricane Katrina.
Ray Barretto: Ray Barretto (1929-2006) was a renowned Puerto Rican-American percussionist, bandleader, and composer who played a pivotal role in the development of Latin jazz. Born in New York City, Barretto began playing timbales in his teens, later incorporating other percussion instruments like congas and bongos into his performances. He led several successful Latin jazz bands throughout his career, most notably the Ray Barretto Orchestra, which was instrumental in fusing traditional Latin rhythms with jazz harmonies and improvisations. Barretto's prolific career earned him numerous awards and accolades, solidifying his legacy as a major figure in the evolution of Latin music.
Aliens vs. Avatars: "Aliens vs. Avatars" is a concept that explores the potential interaction between extraterrestrial life forms ("aliens") and advanced digital avatars, often used in virtual reality or augmented reality applications. This concept has been explored in various forms of media, including science fiction literature, film, and video games. A key aspect of this theme is the potential for conflict or cooperation between these two distinct entities, raising questions about the nature of intelligence, consciousness, and the boundaries between the physical and virtual realms. The concept has also been explored in academic disciplines like philosophy, computer science, and sociology, examining the implications of AI development and the potential for the blurring of lines between human and non-human entities.
Vincenzo Mirabella: Vincenzo Mirabella (1922-2013) was an Italian-American painter known for his vibrant and expressive style. Born in Sicily, Mirabella emigrated to the United States in 1951, settling in New York City. He became recognized for his bold use of color and his depiction of everyday life in the city, often featuring scenes from his Italian heritage. His work has been exhibited widely, including in major galleries and museums across the United States. Notably, Mirabella's art garnered critical acclaim and a loyal following for its energetic and evocative nature, solidifying his place as a significant figure in the New York art scene.
Pakyong Airport: Pakyong Airport, located in the state of Sikkim, India, is the first greenfield airport in the Northeast region of the country.  Inaugurated in 2018, the airport is strategically situated near the capital city of Gangtok, offering convenient access to the state's scenic landscapes and cultural attractions.  The airport's construction presented significant engineering challenges due to its mountainous terrain and limited flat land, requiring a unique approach to runway design and construction.  The airport is a significant development for Sikkim, boosting tourism and economic growth, and showcasing the region's infrastructure development.
Old St. John's Hospital: Old St. John's Hospital, established in 1851 in Brooklyn, New York, was a significant institution in the city's healthcare history. It began as a small, two-story building serving the local community and over the years grew into a complex offering a wide range of medical services. The hospital played a vital role during the American Civil War, treating wounded soldiers and providing crucial medical care to the expanding city. Though it faced financial challenges and ultimately closed its doors in 1975, Old St. John's Hospital left a lasting legacy, contributing to the development of Brooklyn's healthcare infrastructure and serving countless individuals over its 124-year history.
Athletics at the 2014 Commonwealth Games: Athletics at the 2014 Commonwealth Games, held in Glasgow, Scotland, featured a wide range of track and field events. The competition took place from July 23 to August 3, 2014, attracting athletes from across the Commonwealth. Notably, the event saw a strong performance by England, who dominated the medal table with a total of 28 gold medals. Key athletes to watch included Usain Bolt, who won the men's 200 meters, and Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, who secured the women's 100 meters title. The 2014 Commonwealth Games athletics competition showcased the impressive athletic talent from across the Commonwealth.
Rhinella festae: *Rhinella festae* is a species of toad in the Bufonidae family, native to the Andes Mountains of Ecuador and Peru. This toad is characterized by its robust build, warty skin, and distinct coloration, typically displaying a brown or grey background with dark blotches and spots. Described in 1900 by Italian zoologist, G.B. Peracca, *Rhinella festae* inhabits montane grasslands and shrublands at elevations between 2,400 and 3,500 meters.  Despite its relatively small range, *Rhinella festae* is considered to be a common species, although its populations are declining due to habitat loss and fragmentation.
Weight (EP): "Weight (EP)" is the debut extended play (EP) by American singer-songwriter  Lizzo, released on October 15, 2013. The EP was released independently by Lizzo herself, marking the beginning of her career as a solo artist. "Weight (EP)" features a blend of soulful, R&B, and hip-hop influences, showcasing Lizzo's unique vocal range and lyrical prowess.  Its lead single, "Weight," was a critical and commercial success, garnering significant attention for its empowering message and Lizzo's charismatic performance.  This EP established Lizzo as a rising star and laid the foundation for her future musical success.
Fangchanupathum School: Fangchanupathum School is a private, co-educational Buddhist school located in Bangkok, Thailand. Founded in 1962, the school is known for its emphasis on traditional Thai values and Buddhist teachings, integrated into a modern curriculum. Notable alumni include prominent figures in Thai society, reflecting the school's reputation for nurturing academic excellence and character development. Fangchanupathum School is considered one of the leading educational institutions in Thailand, with its commitment to fostering well-rounded individuals who contribute positively to society.
Munich derby: The Munich derby, also known as *Der Klassiker*, is a high-profile football rivalry between German clubs FC Bayern Munich and TSV 1860 Munich.  Dating back to 1900, it is one of the oldest and most fiercely contested derbies in Germany.  The two clubs share a stadium, the Allianz Arena, and have both won major trophies, including the Bundesliga.  The rivalry intensified in the 1960s when both clubs were consistently competing for the league title.  The matchup has witnessed legendary players like Franz Beckenbauer, Gerd Müller, and Lothar Matthäus grace the pitch.
Thai Airways Flight 365: Thai Airways Flight 365 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Bangkok, Thailand to Colombo, Sri Lanka, that crashed on 16 September 1988. The Boeing 737-200 aircraft, operating as flight TG 365, impacted a hillside in the vicinity of Bandaranaike International Airport in Katunayake, Sri Lanka, killing all 137 people on board. The crash was attributed to a combination of factors including an improperly calibrated altimeter, pilot error, and the absence of effective cockpit resource management. The accident led to significant changes in aviation safety procedures, particularly in the areas of cockpit communication and pilot training.
Augasma: "Augasma" is a term used in medieval European literature, particularly in the works of Hildegard von Bingen, to describe a specific type of divine revelation. This concept, which roughly translates to "shining," refers to a supernatural vision or experience that illuminates the mind and heart with spiritual knowledge and understanding. While often associated with mystical visions, Augasma is also used to describe moments of profound insight or inspiration that transcend ordinary human perception. Hildegard, a 12th-century Benedictine abbess, scholar, and visionary, used the concept of Augasma to describe her own profound spiritual experiences, which she believed were direct messages from God. These revelations informed her writings on theology, medicine, and natural science, significantly influencing the intellectual and spiritual life of her time.
John Basedow: John Bernhard Basedow (1723-1790) was a German educator and reformer who is considered one of the founders of the Enlightenment movement in education.  Basedow was known for his advocacy for secular and practical education, promoting the teaching of natural science, languages, and practical skills. He founded the Philanthropinum in Dessau in 1774, the first school in Germany to implement his progressive pedagogical principles. The Philanthropinum emphasized hands-on learning, individual attention, and the development of character traits like honesty and empathy, serving as a model for future educational institutions. Basedow's work and ideas had a significant influence on the development of modern pedagogy, particularly in Germany and Europe.
Alexander's Cathedral: Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, also known as Alexander's Cathedral, is a Russian Orthodox cathedral located in Saint Petersburg, Russia. Constructed between 1826 and 1835, the cathedral is dedicated to Alexander Nevsky, a 13th-century Russian prince who was canonized as a saint. It is considered one of the most significant examples of Russian Empire-era architecture and features a striking neoclassical design with a prominent dome and imposing bell tower. The cathedral houses the tombs of several notable figures, including composers Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky and Modest Mussorgsky, as well as Russian princes and generals. Today, Alexander Nevsky Cathedral serves as an active place of worship and is a popular tourist destination, attracting visitors from around the world.
Cathepsin D: Cathepsin D is a lysosomal aspartic protease, a type of enzyme that breaks down proteins within cells. Found in most eukaryotic cells, it plays a crucial role in various cellular processes, including protein degradation, antigen processing, and programmed cell death (apoptosis).  Cathepsin D is synthesized as a proenzyme and undergoes several processing steps to become active.  Dysregulation of cathepsin D has been implicated in several diseases, including cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and autoimmune diseases.  Notable researchers in the field include Jacques De Duve, who received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1974 for his discovery of lysosomes and their role in cellular digestion.
Buff-fronted owl: The Buff-fronted Owl ( *Glaucidium brasilianum*), also known as the **Tropical Screech Owl**, is a small, widespread owl species found in Central and South America. It is characterized by its distinctive buff-colored facial disc and dark brown barring on its plumage. The Buff-fronted Owl is known for its unique call, a series of high-pitched whistles, and its habit of perching prominently in the open during the day. This adaptable species inhabits a variety of habitats, including forests, woodlands, and even urban areas, and plays a crucial role in controlling insect populations. Its scientific name, *Glaucidium brasilianum*, reflects its original description from Brazil in 1817.
Nonpareil, Nebraska: Nonpareil, Nebraska is a small, unincorporated community located in Otoe County, Nebraska. Established in the late 19th century, the town was a thriving agricultural center, with a population reaching over 200 residents in the early 20th century. Today, Nonpareil has a significantly smaller population and relies primarily on agriculture for its economy. The community is known for its rural charm and its historic buildings, including a former schoolhouse and a general store. Notable figures associated with Nonpareil include local farmer and community leader, John Smith, who played a key role in the town's development in the early 1900s.
Jack Nethercutt II: Jack Nethercutt II (1927-2012) was an American entrepreneur, car collector, and philanthropist known for his vast collection of classic automobiles. He founded Nethercutt Collection, a museum and research facility in Sylmar, California, showcasing over 250 vehicles, including some of the rarest and most significant cars ever built.  Nethercutt's passion for automobiles began in his youth, and he amassed his collection through decades of dedicated searching and preservation. His efforts played a significant role in preserving automotive history and providing access to rare vehicles for enthusiasts and scholars alike.  Beyond his automotive passion, Nethercutt also established the Nethercutt Educational Foundation, supporting various educational initiatives in Southern California.
Seven Swordsmen: "Seven Swordsmen" is a popular term in Chinese martial arts fiction and film, often referring to a group of seven highly skilled swordsmen who work together to achieve a common goal. This concept, originating in Chinese literature, has been popularized in numerous wuxia novels, films, and television shows. Notably, the 1978 film "Seven Swords" by Chang Cheh, depicting a group of swordsmen defending a village against a tyrannical warlord, became a landmark production and contributed significantly to the genre's popularity. Other adaptations, such as the 2005 film "Seven Swords," further popularized the theme, while various iterations explored different narratives and character dynamics, solidifying "Seven Swordsmen" as a recurring motif in Chinese martial arts storytelling.
Rede Brasil de Televis\u00e3o: Rede Brasil de Televisão, commonly known as Rede Brasil, is a Brazilian television network that was launched on January 1, 1981, by businessman and politician Paulo Machado de Carvalho. The network was initially known for its focus on sports programming, particularly soccer, and its innovative programming that challenged the established order of Brazilian television. However, Rede Brasil struggled financially and faced competition from established networks, ultimately leading to its closure in 1998.  Despite its short lifespan, Rede Brasil left a mark on Brazilian television by introducing new concepts and fostering a sense of national pride through its sports coverage.
Partners (statue): "Partners" is a bronze sculpture by the American artist George Segal, depicting a couple seated on a park bench. The work, installed in 1984 in Union Square Park in New York City, was commissioned as part of the city's Percent for Art program. "Partners" is significant for its realistic portrayal of ordinary people and its placement in a public space, making it accessible to all. The sculpture's simple composition and the poignant intimacy of the figures have made it a popular landmark and a symbol of love and companionship in the city.
President of the Czech Republic: The President of the Czech Republic is the head of state and the supreme commander of the Czech Armed Forces. The office was established in 1993 following the dissolution of Czechoslovakia. The president is elected by direct popular vote for a five-year term, with a maximum of two consecutive terms. The current president is Petr Pavel, who took office in March 2023. The president's primary functions include appointing the prime minister, signing legislation into law, and representing the Czech Republic in international affairs.
Aquaman (film): "Aquaman" (2018) is a superhero film based on the DC Comics character of the same name. Directed by James Wan, the film stars Jason Momoa as Arthur Curry, the half-human, half-Atlantean heir to the underwater kingdom of Atlantis. The film follows Arthur's journey to embrace his destiny as Aquaman and unite the seven kingdoms of Atlantis against his half-brother, Orm (Patrick Wilson), who seeks to conquer the surface world. "Aquaman" was a critical and commercial success, grossing over $1.1 billion worldwide and becoming the highest-grossing DC Extended Universe film at the time. The film was praised for its action sequences, visual effects, and Momoa's performance as the titular hero.
Hotel Utah (San Francisco, California): The Hotel Utah, a landmark building in San Francisco, California, was built in 1908 and was a prominent hotel for over half a century.  Originally named the Utah Hotel, it was designed by renowned architect, William Polk, and served as a gathering place for the city's elite and notable figures.  The hotel, with its grand ballroom and ornate interior, was a popular venue for social events and business meetings. The Hotel Utah was renovated and rebranded as The Hotel Nikko San Francisco in 1982.  However, the building retains its historical significance as a reminder of San Francisco's vibrant past and its architectural heritage.
Wood Lane tube station (Central line): Wood Lane tube station is a London Underground station on the Central line, located in the White City area of West London. Opened in 1947 as part of the Central line's extension westwards, the station replaced the nearby White City station, which served the 1908 Franco-British Exhibition. Designed by Charles Holden, the station's distinctive features include its curved platform and its use of brick and concrete. It is a notable stop for those visiting the nearby Television Centre and Westfield London shopping center, making it a significant transport hub in the area.
23rd Infantry Regiment (Imperial Japanes: The 23rd Infantry Regiment was an infantry regiment of the Imperial Japanese Army, formed in 1888 as part of the IJA's modernization efforts.  The regiment saw action in various conflicts, including the First Sino-Japanese War, the Russo-Japanese War, and World War II. Notable battles the regiment participated in include the Battle of Mukden (1905), the Battle of Shanghai (1937), and the Battle of Luzon (1945). During World War II, the regiment was part of the 11th Division, which was deployed to the Philippines and saw heavy fighting against American forces. After Japan's surrender in 1945, the regiment was disbanded.
The Cr\u00fcxshadows: The Crüxshadows is an American gothic rock band formed in 1992 in Los Angeles, California, by vocalist and songwriter Rogue. Known for their dark, atmospheric soundscapes and theatrical live performances, the band has released 11 studio albums, including their most commercially successful, "The Burning Wheel" (2001). Their music blends gothic, industrial, and electronic influences, creating a unique sound that has earned them a dedicated following. The Crüxshadows have toured extensively throughout the United States and Europe, and their music has been featured in numerous television shows and films.
Ph\u1ea1m H\u1ea3i Y\u1ebfn: Phạm Hải Yến is a Vietnamese professional badminton player, known for her skill in the women's doubles category.  She has represented Vietnam in numerous international tournaments, including the Southeast Asian Games, where she won a bronze medal in 2017.  Yến's playing style is characterized by strong net play and powerful smashes.  She is a significant figure in Vietnamese badminton, inspiring younger players and contributing to the nation's rising profile in the sport.  Her career highlights include her consistent performance in the BWF World Tour, where she has secured several top-10 finishes.
Tripoli, Libya: Tripoli, Libya, is the capital and largest city of the North African country. It is located on the Mediterranean coast and has a long history dating back to antiquity, having been founded as a Phoenician settlement around the 7th century BC. The city has been ruled by various empires throughout history, including the Romans, Arabs, Ottomans, and Italians. Today, Tripoli is a major economic and cultural center, with a population of over 2 million people. It is home to numerous historic landmarks, museums, and cultural institutions, including the ancient Roman ruins of Leptis Magna, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Armed Police Force: An armed police force is a law enforcement agency equipped with firearms and trained to use lethal force in specific situations. These units typically operate under the authority of a national or regional government and are responsible for maintaining public order, enforcing laws, and protecting citizens. The use of armed police forces is a complex issue, often sparking debates about civilian rights, police accountability, and the appropriate level of force in society. Historically, the concept of armed police forces emerged in the 19th century, driven by factors like urbanization, industrialization, and the need to control crime and unrest. Notable examples include the Metropolitan Police in London, established in 1829, which played a pivotal role in the development of modern policing.
Qixia Mountain: Qixia Mountain, located in the city of Qingdao, Shandong Province, China, is a prominent landmark known for its diverse geological formations and historical significance. The mountain, also known as Laoshan, has been a revered site for Taoist and Buddhist practices since ancient times, with numerous temples and monasteries built within its slopes. Notable features include the "Stone Buddha" and the "Jade Spring", which are believed to possess spiritual power. The mountain's unique rock formations, created by millions of years of erosion, attract tourists and climbers alike, offering scenic views and a glimpse into the region's geological history.
Chetwode: "Chetwode" refers to a family of British military officers, most notably Field Marshal Lord Chetwode, who served as the Commander-in-Chief of India from 1930 to 1935. The family's military lineage dates back to the 17th century, with numerous members serving in the British Army across various conflicts. The Chetwode family played a significant role in the history of the British Empire, particularly in India, where their contributions to the Indian Army are deeply rooted. Lord Chetwode, in particular, is remembered for his efforts in modernizing the Indian Army and his significant influence on the development of the military institution during his time as Commander-in-Chief.
Bruce Bennett: Bruce Bennett (1909–1987) was a prolific American actor, known primarily for his roles in Westerns and action films.  His career spanned over four decades, beginning in the 1930s and ending in the 1970s, with notable appearances in films like "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" (1948), "The Wild Bunch" (1969), and "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" (1966).  Often cast as a rugged and menacing villain, he was a familiar face in countless B-Westerns and action films, cementing his place as a stalwart figure in American cinema.  He was also the brother of well-known actor, Constance Bennett.
VMF-123: VMF-123, also known as the "Fighting Twelfth", was a United States Marine Corps fighter squadron that saw extensive action during World War II. Established in 1941, the squadron initially flew the Brewster F2A Buffalo and later transitioned to the Grumman F4F Wildcat. VMF-123 gained fame for its performance during the Guadalcanal Campaign, where it engaged in fierce dogfights against Japanese aircraft. Notably, the squadron's commanding officer, Major John L. Smith, was awarded the Medal of Honor for his actions during the campaign, highlighting the unit's bravery and effectiveness in combat. After the war, VMF-123 was deactivated and its legacy continues to inspire future generations of Marine aviators.
Jimmy Keegan: Jimmy Keegan (born 1950) is a Northern Irish professional footballer who played as a forward. He spent the majority of his career with Newcastle United, making over 300 appearances for the club between 1968 and 1980. Keegan was known for his prolific scoring record, particularly during the 1970s, and is considered a legend at St. James' Park. He was also capped by Northern Ireland on 16 occasions, scoring four goals. Following his retirement from playing, Keegan had coaching roles with both Newcastle United and the Northern Ireland national team.
Friends School of Baltimore: Friends School of Baltimore is a private Quaker school in Baltimore, Maryland, founded in 1784. It is one of the oldest schools in the United States and is known for its strong academic program, emphasizing Quaker values of peace, simplicity, and equality. Notable alumni include the former U.S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist David Ignatius. The school's curriculum incorporates Quaker principles and encourages student participation in community service and social justice initiatives.
Gloria Wigney: Gloria Wigney (1922-2009) was a prominent figure in the American women's suffrage movement. A dedicated activist, Wigney began her career in the 1940s, working with organizations like the League of Women Voters to advocate for equal rights for women.  She played a pivotal role in the campaign for the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA), organizing rallies and mobilizing support across the United States. Her efforts contributed significantly to the national debate on women's suffrage and helped pave the way for the eventual passage of the ERA in 1972. Wigney's legacy is remembered as a tireless advocate for women's rights and a champion for social justice.
Stolen Childhood: "Stolen Childhood" is a term used to describe the denial of basic childhood rights and experiences due to factors such as poverty, conflict, exploitation, or abuse. This concept highlights the severe impact of these situations on children's physical, emotional, and intellectual development, depriving them of opportunities for education, play, and a safe and nurturing environment. The term has been used in various contexts, including discussions about child labor, trafficking, and war-torn regions where children are forced to become soldiers or refugees. Organizations like UNICEF and Save the Children actively advocate for policies and programs to address the issue of stolen childhoods and ensure that children can live healthy, safe, and fulfilling lives.
Faton Peci: Faton Peci is a renowned Albanian singer and songwriter, known for his unique blend of traditional Albanian folk music with contemporary pop influences. Born in 1981 in Prishtina, Kosovo, Peci began his musical journey as a young child, participating in numerous talent shows and competitions.  He gained national recognition in the early 2000s with hit songs like "Dashuri e Vërtetë" and "Nuk Je Ti", becoming one of the most popular Albanian singers of his generation. Peci's music has earned him several awards, including "Best Male Artist" at the prestigious Albanian Music Awards.  He continues to perform and record music, remaining a prominent figure in Albanian popular culture.
Betzenberg Wildlife Park: Betzenberg Wildlife Park is a zoological park located in Kaiserslautern, Germany, established in 1967. The park is home to a diverse collection of animals representing various species from around the world, including wolves, bears, lions, and various birds.  The park's main objective is to educate visitors about wildlife conservation and the importance of protecting biodiversity. It features spacious enclosures designed to simulate the animals' natural habitats, providing visitors with an engaging and immersive experience. Betzenberg Wildlife Park is a popular destination for families and nature enthusiasts, attracting thousands of visitors annually.
Way Down Here: "Way Down Here" is a 1994 short story by the American author, John Updike. It is part of his collection "Rabbit at Rest", which explores the later life of the protagonist Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom. The story focuses on Rabbit's reflection on his life, particularly his relationship with his wife Janice, as he attends the funeral of a former lover, Priscilla.  "Way Down Here" is considered a significant piece in Updike's "Rabbit" tetralogy, as it reveals the complexity of Rabbit's emotions and his struggle to reconcile with his past.
Murray Deaker: Murray Deaker (1940-2021) was a prominent Canadian sports broadcaster known for his long and successful career in radio. He was a popular figure on Toronto radio, particularly for his work on sports talk shows and his role as the longtime play-by-play voice for the Toronto Maple Leafs on radio. Deaker's career spanned over five decades, beginning in the 1960s, and he was known for his engaging personality, insightful commentary, and his ability to connect with listeners. He was also a passionate advocate for Canadian sports and a respected figure in the broadcasting industry. His contributions to sports broadcasting in Canada continue to be recognized and remembered.
Acetone (album): "Acetone" is the second studio album by American indie rock band Modest Mouse, released in 2000.  The album was recorded in 1999 and produced by the band alongside their longtime collaborator, John Congleton. "Acetone"  marked a significant departure from their previous work, featuring a more polished and layered sound, incorporating elements of alternative rock, experimental music, and electronic influences.  The album's success solidified the band's growing popularity and established them as a major force in the indie rock scene, with singles like "Ocean Breathes Salty" and "Gravity Rides Everything" achieving widespread recognition.
Nodopus: "Nodopus" is a genus of cephalopods belonging to the family Octopodidae. This genus, which comprises only two species,  *Nodopus antonjannaschii* and *Nodopus pyramidus*, is notable for its deep-sea dwelling and its unique morphology. These octopuses are characterized by their  bulbous bodies and prominent dorsal "nodules," giving them their name. *Nodopus antonjannaschii* was discovered in 1988 near hydrothermal vents in the eastern Pacific Ocean, while *Nodopus pyramidus* was discovered in 2016 in the Atlantic Ocean. These discoveries highlight the vast diversity of life in the deep sea and its capacity for adaptation to extreme environments.
The Good Wife season 6: "The Good Wife" season 6, airing from October 2014 to May 2015, marked a significant turning point in the legal drama series.  The season introduced new characters and storylines, including the arrival of the formidable investigator,  "Finn Polmar," played by  "The Good Wife" veteran actor  "Cush Jumbo," who quickly became a fan favorite.  The season saw the departure of  "Josh Charles" as  "Will Gardner," after his unexpected death in the season 5 finale, and the introduction of new romantic interests for  "Alicia Florrick," including  "Jason Crouse" played by "Jeffrey Dean Morgan."  Season 6 explored themes of power, ambition, and redemption, culminating in a shocking and dramatic season finale that left viewers eager for more.
South Australian National Football Leagu: The South Australian National Football League (SANFL), founded in 1877, is the oldest professional Australian rules football competition in the world. Based in South Australia, the league has 10 clubs, with the Adelaide Crows and Port Adelaide Power representing the state in the Australian Football League (AFL).  Notable figures in the SANFL's history include the legendary "Polly" Farmer, who played for the West Adelaide Football Club and was inducted into the Australian Football Hall of Fame in 1996. The SANFL has been instrumental in fostering the development of Australian rules football in South Australia and has produced numerous AFL players, including several Brownlow Medalists.
Nichols Canyon (horse): Nichols Canyon was a renowned American Thoroughbred racehorse who competed in the early 20th century. Bred by Harry Payne Whitney and owned by the prestigious Belair Stud, Nichols Canyon won the prestigious Kentucky Derby in 1923, solidifying his place in horse racing history. He went on to have a successful career, winning multiple stakes races and becoming a leading sire.  Notable among his offspring was the filly,  "Top Flight", a champion filly herself in 1931. Nichols Canyon's legacy continues to influence the world of Thoroughbred racing through his bloodlines, which have produced numerous successful runners.
Good Girls Revolt: "Good Girls Revolt" is a 2010 non-fiction book by Lynn Povich that chronicles the 1970 class-action sex discrimination lawsuit against Newsweek magazine, filed by 46 female employees who were denied promotions and equal pay. The lawsuit, filed in 1970, was a landmark case that helped spark the feminist movement in the United States. The lawsuit, which was ultimately settled out of court, was led by a group of women who were determined to fight for equal opportunities in the workplace. The book, which has been praised for its detailed and insightful look at a pivotal moment in American history, has been adapted into a television series of the same name.
Dan Laustsen: Dan Laustsen is a Danish cinematographer known for his distinctive style characterized by rich, deep colors and meticulous framing. He began his career in the early 1990s, working primarily in Danish television before gaining recognition for his work in Lars von Trier's films, including "Breaking the Waves" (1996) and "Dancer in the Dark" (2000).  Laustsen's collaboration with von Trier spanned over two decades, resulting in several critically acclaimed films that solidified his reputation as a master of visual storytelling. Beyond his work with von Trier, Laustsen has collaborated with other prominent directors, showcasing his versatility and ability to adapt to diverse cinematic styles.
Shina Dark: "Shina Dark" is a term primarily used in the context of Pakistani politics and refers to a specific faction within the Pakistani military establishment. This faction, often associated with the ISI, is known for its perceived influence over Pakistani foreign policy, particularly in regards to Afghanistan and India. The term "Shina" is believed to be a coded reference to the origin of this faction, with some sources suggesting its members are from the Gilgit-Baltistan region. While the existence of this faction and its specific influence remain debated, the concept of "Shina Dark" has been a recurring theme in Pakistani political discourse, particularly during periods of political instability.
Laurent Degos: Laurent Degos (born 1958) is a French dermatologist and researcher known for his significant contributions to the fields of dermatology and immunology. He is a professor of dermatology at the University of Paris-Descartes and the head of the dermatology department at the Cochin Hospital in Paris. Degos's research focuses on the pathogenesis of autoimmune skin diseases, particularly bullous pemphigoid, and the development of novel therapeutic approaches. He is a highly respected figure in the scientific community, having authored numerous publications and received several prestigious awards, including the prestigious  "Prix de l'Académie Nationale de Médecine" in 2013.
Tallinn Cathedral of the Transfiguration: The Tallinn Cathedral of the Transfiguration of Our Lord, also known as Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, is a prominent Russian Orthodox cathedral located in Tallinn, Estonia. Constructed between 1894 and 1900, the cathedral stands as a symbol of Russian influence in the region and is a prime example of Russian Revival architecture.  It is dedicated to the Transfiguration of Jesus and features striking onion domes, vibrant mosaics, and ornate interiors.  The cathedral has been a focal point of Estonian-Russian cultural and religious tensions, with its construction sparking protests and its presence remaining controversial.
David Clary: David Clary is a renowned theoretical chemist known for his pioneering work in developing rigorous quantum mechanical methods for studying molecular collisions. His research has significantly advanced the understanding of chemical reactions, particularly those involving reactive scattering and energy transfer. Born in 1947, Clary received his doctorate from Cambridge University in 1974 and went on to become a Professor at the University of Cambridge and later the University of Oxford. He is recognized for his influential contributions to the field, including the development of the "Clary method" for calculating reaction rates and his studies on the dynamics of atmospheric reactions.
William Robertson (urban missionary): William Robertson (1823–1891) was a prominent Scottish urban missionary and social reformer. He dedicated his life to improving the lives of the poor and marginalized in Glasgow, Scotland, where he founded numerous organizations dedicated to housing, education, and healthcare. Robertson's work was particularly focused on the plight of children and families living in extreme poverty. Notably, he established the "Shelter for Homeless Boys" in 1861, which later became the "Boys' Brigade," a globally recognized youth organization. His efforts helped to raise awareness of social issues and inspire reform movements throughout the 19th century.
The Gladiators: Galactic Circus Games: "The Gladiators: Galactic Circus Games" is a fictional event within the Star Wars universe, a popular form of entertainment in the Outer Rim Territories. The Games, first established on the planet Ryloth during the early days of the Galactic Republic, featured fierce competitions between gladiators from various alien species. Participants, often prisoners of war or criminals, fought to the death or until a victor was declared by a panel of judges. The spectacle was renowned for its brutality and elaborate displays of alien weaponry, with the Ryloth Games eventually gaining notoriety across the galaxy. Notable figures like the Twi'lek Jedi Knight Aayla Secura were known to have attended these Games, providing a glimpse into the complex cultural and political dynamics of the galaxy.
S\u01a1n T\u00e2y campaign: The Sơn Tây campaign was a major military operation launched by the French Army in Vietnam in 1883. The objective was to capture the fortified city of Sơn Tây, which served as a stronghold for the Black Flag Army under the leadership of the Chinese general, Liu Yongfu. The campaign, lasting from December 1883 to January 1884, resulted in a decisive French victory, marking a significant step in their conquest of northern Vietnam. The capture of Sơn Tây weakened the resistance of Vietnamese forces and paved the way for the establishment of French control over the region. Notable figures involved include French General Charles-Théodore Millot, who led the campaign, and Liu Yongfu, whose resistance was ultimately overcome.
Ben McCartney: Ben McCartney is a Canadian singer-songwriter known for his blend of folk, pop, and rock influences. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, in 1995, McCartney began performing at a young age, eventually forming the band "The Burning Hell" in 2011. He has released several albums as a solo artist, including "The Great Pretender" (2017) and "Everything Beautiful is a Lie" (2020), which have garnered critical acclaim for their introspective lyrics and raw emotional depth. Notably, his song "The Ballad of the Lonesome Cowboy" became a popular single in Canada and contributed to his growing recognition as a rising talent within the indie music scene.
Acacia williamsiana: *Acacia williamsiana*, also known as the "Western Australian Blackwood" or "Blackwood Wattle," is a species of flowering wattle native to southwestern Western Australia. This tree is prized for its dark, durable timber, which has been used extensively in furniture making and other woodworking applications. The species was first described in 1855 by English botanist Ferdinand von Mueller, who named it after William Henry Harvey, an Irish botanist who contributed significantly to the study of Australian flora. *Acacia williamsiana* is a fast-growing, drought-tolerant tree, making it a valuable species for both its commercial and ecological value.
David and Gladys Wright House: The David and Gladys Wright House, also known as the "Usonian Automatic House," is a residential structure designed by renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright in 1952 for his son David and daughter-in-law Gladys. Located in Phoenix, Arizona, the house is a prime example of Wright's Usonian style, characterized by its emphasis on simplicity, affordability, and organic integration with its surroundings. The house features innovative design elements such as cantilevered roofs, built-in furniture, and a central courtyard, reflecting Wright's philosophy of harmonizing architecture with nature. The David and Gladys Wright House is a significant landmark in the history of modern architecture and remains a popular destination for architecture enthusiasts.
Clan Innes: Clan Innes is a Highland Scottish clan that traces its ancestry back to the 12th century.  The clan's traditional seat was at Innes House in Moray, Scotland, and its members played a significant role in the history of the region. Notable figures include Sir Robert Innes, who served as Lord Advocate of Scotland in the 17th century, and the Innes family's involvement in the Jacobite uprisings of the 18th century. The clan motto, "Fide et Fortitudine," reflects the Innes' commitment to loyalty and strength. The clan continues to be recognized today, with various branches of the Innes family residing in Scotland and around the world.
Minuscule 544: Minuscule 544 (Gregory-Aland number; S. 1244), is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament, dated to the 11th century. It is currently housed at the Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana in Florence, Italy. The manuscript contains the complete text of the Gospels, with the text of the Book of Revelation lacking. Minuscule 544 is considered to be a significant manuscript due to its unique textual variants, particularly in the Gospel of Luke, which differ from the majority of other manuscripts. This manuscript is of interest to textual critics who study the history and transmission of the New Testament text.
USS Siskin: The USS *Siskin* (AMc-71) was a coastal minesweeper built for the United States Navy during World War II. Launched in 1941, she served in the Atlantic Theater, primarily off the coast of the eastern United States, to protect American ports and shipping lanes from German submarine attacks. The *Siskin* was later transferred to the United States Coast Guard and served as the USCGC *Siskin* (WLM-211) until being decommissioned in 1947. While not involved in direct combat, she played a crucial role in supporting the war effort by ensuring the safe passage of vital supplies and personnel.
Katayamalite: "Katayamalite" is a rare mineral named after Japanese geologist Nobuo Katayama, who discovered it in 1975. It is a hydrated calcium sulfate mineral, chemically represented as CaSO₄·2H₂O, and is characterized by its translucent, colorless to white crystals with a monoclinic crystal system. Katayamalite is found in association with gypsum and anhydrite in evaporite deposits and is primarily known from its type locality in the Shimane Prefecture of Japan. Its significance lies in its rarity and its contribution to the understanding of mineral formation processes in evaporative environments.
Astilbe japonica: *Astilbe japonica*, commonly known as Japanese astilbe, is a species of flowering plant in the family Saxifragaceae. Native to Japan, this perennial plant is highly valued for its showy plumes of feathery flowers in shades of pink, white, and red.  *Astilbe japonica* was first described by Carl Peter Thunberg in 1784 and has since been widely cultivated in gardens around the world, with numerous cultivars bred for various colors, flower shapes, and heights.  This species is particularly adaptable, thriving in shady and moist conditions, making it a popular choice for woodland gardens and landscape designs.
Oulu Castle: Oulu Castle, located in the city of Oulu, Finland, was a medieval stone castle built in the 14th century.  The castle served as a strategic stronghold for the Swedish Crown, controlling trade routes and defending against Russian incursions.  Notable features of the castle included its fortified walls, a tower, and a moat.  After a fire in 1713, the castle was abandoned and eventually demolished in the 19th century.  Today, only a few remnants remain, including parts of the foundation and a well, serving as a reminder of the region's rich history.
Gadsar Lake: Gadsar Lake, nestled in the Zanskar Valley of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, is a high-altitude glacial lake renowned for its scenic beauty and ecological significance. Situated at an elevation of approximately 4,500 meters (14,764 feet), the lake is a vital source of water for the surrounding region and serves as a habitat for diverse flora and fauna, including rare migratory birds. The lake's history is intertwined with the cultural heritage of the Zanskar people, who have long relied upon its waters for sustenance and spiritual practices. The picturesque landscape and remote location of Gadsar Lake make it a popular destination for adventurous trekkers and nature enthusiasts seeking a unique experience in the Himalayas.
Des Murs's wiretail: "Des Murs's wiretail" (**Leptophis mexicanus**) is a non-venomous snake species native to Central America and Mexico. It is characterized by its slender body, vibrant green coloration, and prominent lateral stripes that create the appearance of a wire. Described by French zoologist Auguste Duméril in 1853, the species is notable for its agility and arboreal lifestyle, spending most of its time in trees and shrubs. The wiretail primarily preys on smaller vertebrates and invertebrates, relying on its speed and camouflage to ambush its prey.
Giorgio Biandrata: Giorgio Biandrata (1510–1588) was an Italian antitrinitarian theologian who played a significant role in the development of early Unitarianism. He was born in Turin, Italy, and became a prominent figure in the Italian Reformation. Biandrata was a proponent of the Socinian view of Christ, which rejected the Trinity doctrine and emphasized the humanity of Jesus.  He was forced to flee Italy due to persecution and spent time in Transylvania, Poland, and England, where he continued to advocate for his beliefs. Biandrata's work helped to establish a foundation for the development of Unitarianism, a religious movement that continues to this day.
Wilkes University: Wilkes University is a private, non-profit university located in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. Founded in 1933 as Wilkes College, the institution adopted its current name in 1989. Wilkes University offers over 70 undergraduate and graduate programs across its five colleges: the College of Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences; the College of Business and Entrepreneurship; the College of Education; the College of Engineering; and the College of Health and Sciences. Notable alumni include former Pennsylvania Governor Tom Ridge and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist John Feehan. The university has a strong emphasis on experiential learning, with active programs in research, internships, and study abroad.
Puerto Rico Highway 180: Puerto Rico Highway 180, also known as the "Expreso de Diego" (Diego Expressway), is a 14.7-mile (23.7 km) controlled-access highway in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The highway connects the metropolitan area with the municipalities of Carolina and Trujillo Alto.  The expressway was constructed in stages, beginning in 1969 and fully completed in 1984.  It features a cloverleaf interchange at its intersection with PR-1 and PR-3, providing a major connection for traffic entering and exiting the San Juan metropolitan area.  The highway is named after Diego de Almagro, the Spanish conquistador who led an expedition to Peru in the 16th century.
Trey Caldwell: Trey Caldwell is an American professional basketball player who currently plays for the South Bay Lakers of the NBA G League. Caldwell, a 6'6" guard, is known for his versatility and athleticism. He played college basketball at the University of Southern California, where he averaged 10.1 points and 4.4 rebounds per game in his senior season. After going undrafted in the 2021 NBA Draft, Caldwell signed with the Los Angeles Lakers and played for their G League affiliate, the South Bay Lakers.  He has also played in the NBA Summer League, showcasing his skills to potential NBA teams.
Alberto Mina: Alberto Mina (born December 18, 1986) is a prominent Argentine professional mixed martial artist. Known for his striking and submission skills, Mina has competed in major organizations such as Bellator MMA and the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC). He is a former Bellator Middleweight Champion, winning the title in 2013. Mina is notable for his aggressive fighting style and his willingness to engage in exciting battles. He holds a professional record of 13 wins and 8 losses, showcasing his resilience and ability to compete against top-level opponents.
Peripherin: Peripherin is a protein found in the retina of the eye, specifically in the photoreceptor cells known as rods and cones. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the structure and function of these cells, contributing to the process of vision. Peripherin is a component of the outer segment of photoreceptor cells, where it interacts with other proteins to form a complex network that supports the light-sensitive rhodopsin molecule. The gene encoding peripherin is located on chromosome 6 and mutations in this gene can lead to various retinal diseases, including retinitis pigmentosa, a group of inherited disorders that cause progressive vision loss.
2007\u201308 Michigan State Spartans men: The 2007-08 Michigan State Spartans men's basketball team was a highly successful squad led by head coach Tom Izzo. The team finished the regular season with a 29-4 record, capturing the Big Ten Conference regular season title. Their dominant performance earned them a No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament, where they reached the Sweet Sixteen before falling to the eventual national champions, the Kansas Jayhawks.  Key players for the Spartans included senior guard Drew Neitzel, who was named the Big Ten Player of the Year, and junior forward Goran Suton, who led the team in rebounding.
