He has received numerous awards for his artistic contributions, including the "Best Artist" award at the 2015 Tehran International Photography Festival.
Yuanlin railway station: Yuanlin railway station is a major railway station located in Yuanlin City, Changhua County, Taiwan.  Opened in 1908, the station serves as a crucial hub for the Taiwan Railways Administration's (TRA) Western Line, connecting passengers to major cities like Taipei and Kaohsiung.  Notable features include the station's distinctive arched roof structure and its role in facilitating trade and transportation within the region.  Yuanlin station has undergone several renovations and expansions over the years, reflecting its continuous importance as a key transportation node in central Taiwan.
Ahn Jae-hwan: Ahn Jae-hwan (1972-2008) was a South Korean actor known for his comedic roles in television dramas and films. He rose to prominence in the late 1990s with his appearances in popular sitcoms such as "Three Guys and One Girl" and "Nonstop." He also starred in several successful dramas, including "The Full Sun" and "The Legend."  Tragically, Ahn Jae-hwan died by suicide in 2008 at the age of 36, leaving behind a legacy of memorable performances and a lasting impact on the Korean entertainment industry.
Gaylord Perry: Gaylord Perry (born 1938) is a former Major League Baseball pitcher, renowned for his masterful control of the spitball, a pitch considered illegal in Major League Baseball.  He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1991, after a long and successful career that saw him win 314 games, earning him a reputation as one of the toughest pitchers to hit in the game.  Perry's career spanned from 1962 to 1983, during which time he played for seven teams, including the San Francisco Giants, Cleveland Indians, and Texas Rangers. He is considered a pioneer of the "control" pitcher, a style that emphasizes meticulous pitch placement and deception over raw velocity.
Charles H. Tenney: Charles H. Tenney (1893-1975) was an American educator and author who became a prominent figure in the John Birch Society, a conservative political organization founded in 1958. Tenney's career was marked by his strong anti-communist views, which he expressed through his writings and his role as the Society's national director of education. His most notable work, "The American's Creed," was widely circulated by the John Birch Society and promoted an anti-communist agenda. Tenney's influence extended beyond the John Birch Society, contributing to the broader conservative movement in the United States during the Cold War era.
HMAS Vampire (D11): HMAS Vampire (D11) was a V-class destroyer that served in the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) from 1943 to 1959. Built in the United Kingdom, the vessel served during World War II, primarily in the Mediterranean and the Pacific. Notable engagements included the Battle of Cape Matapan in 1941, where Vampire and her sister ships sank the Italian cruiser *Fiume*. After the war, Vampire was modernized and remained in service until being decommissioned and sold for scrap in 1959. The ship's service record exemplifies the contributions of the RAN to Allied efforts during World War II and showcases the evolution of naval warfare in the mid-20th century.
Billy G. Mills: Billy G. Mills (born June 21, 1938) is an Oglala Lakota runner who is best known for his stunning victory in the 10,000 meters at the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Mills' win, achieved against all odds as an unknown runner from the Pine Ridge Reservation, is considered one of the greatest upsets in Olympic history. He was the first American man to win the 10,000 meters in the Olympics and only the second Native American to win an individual gold medal in the Games. Mills' success brought international attention to Native American athletes and inspired a generation of Native American youth.
G\u00f6sta T\u00f6rner (musician): Gösta Törner (1932-2000) was a Swedish jazz musician, known primarily as a saxophonist and clarinetist. His musical career spanned over four decades, during which he performed and recorded extensively throughout Scandinavia. Törner was a prominent figure in the Swedish jazz scene, contributing to the development of a unique Scandinavian jazz style characterized by improvisation and folk influences. He was a founding member of the renowned Swedish jazz group "The Stockholm Jazz Workshop" in 1959, which gained international recognition for its innovative and experimental approach to jazz. Throughout his career, Törner collaborated with numerous prominent Scandinavian jazz musicians and received several awards for his contributions to music.
HMS E4: HMS E4 was a British E-class submarine commissioned in 1914.  Built by Vickers at Barrow-in-Furness, E4 served in the North Sea during World War I, participating in patrols and attacks on German shipping.  During the war, E4 was credited with sinking two German vessels: the merchant ship *Alfried Krupp* in 1916 and the auxiliary cruiser *SMS Hela* in 1917.  E4 was sold for scrapping in 1920, ending a short but eventful career.
Disco Fever (album): "Disco Fever" is the debut studio album by American disco group The Trammps, released in 1976. It was a commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard Top Soul Albums chart and number two on the Billboard 200. The album spawned several hit singles, including the title track "Disco Fever", which became a disco anthem and reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100.  The album is credited with helping to popularize the disco genre and is considered a landmark release in the history of disco music. The album's success was partly due to the songwriting and production talents of  Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff, who were renowned for their work with the Philadelphia International Records label.
Potchefstroom Commando: The Potchefstroom Commando was a military unit of the Transvaal Boers during the First Boer War (1880-1881) and Second Boer War (1899-1902). Formed in Potchefstroom, a town in the Transvaal Republic, the commando played a significant role in both conflicts. During the First Boer War, the Potchefstroom Commando, led by Commandant-General Piet Joubert, participated in the Siege of Potchefstroom, a pivotal battle where Boer forces successfully repelled British forces. In the Second Boer War, the commando fought alongside other Boer units against the British Empire, engaging in several battles and skirmishes, ultimately contributing to the prolonged and ultimately unsuccessful Boer resistance.
Wang Leehom: Wang Leehom (born May 17, 1976) is a Taiwanese-American singer, songwriter, record producer, actor, and director. Known for his blend of R&B, pop, and classical influences, Leehom has been a major figure in the Mandarin pop scene since the late 1990s. He has released numerous commercially successful albums, including "Forever Love" (1995) and "The One" (2004), and has starred in films such as "Lust, Caution" (2007) and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny" (2016). Leehom's career has been marked by numerous accolades, including 15 Golden Melody Awards, the highest music honor in Taiwan.
Limited liability: Limited liability is a legal concept that protects the personal assets of business owners from being seized to pay for business debts. This principle, first established in England in the 1800s, allows individuals to invest in companies without risking their personal wealth beyond their initial investment. The concept is fundamental to modern business structures, particularly corporations, as it encourages investment and risk-taking by shielding entrepreneurs from potentially crippling financial liabilities. Limited liability has been instrumental in the development of large-scale businesses and the growth of the global economy.
Thompson Square (album): "Thompson Square (album)" is the self-titled debut studio album by American country music duo Thompson Square, released on July 13, 2010, by Stoney Creek Records. The album features the hit singles "Are You Gonna Kiss Me or Not" and "If I Didn't Have You", both of which reached number one on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart. The album was produced by Dann Huff and features a mix of traditional and contemporary country music sounds. "Thompson Square" received positive reviews from critics, who praised the duo's strong vocals and songwriting skills. It was certified Gold by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for sales of over 500,000 copies.
Jeff Lerg: Jeff Lerg is a former American professional ice hockey goaltender. He played in the National Hockey League (NHL) with the Carolina Hurricanes and the San Jose Sharks, as well as for numerous teams in the American Hockey League (AHL). Lerg was drafted 164th overall by the Hurricanes in the 2005 NHL Entry Draft after playing collegiate hockey at the University of Michigan. His NHL career spanned from 2009 to 2012, during which he recorded 12 wins and a .906 save percentage. Lerg is known for his strong performances in the AHL, where he was a Calder Cup champion with the Chicago Wolves in 2008.
Elachista grotenfelti: *Elachista grotenfelti* is a moth species belonging to the family Elachistidae, known for its association with the native bunchgrass *Stipa pulchra*. First described by American entomologist Annette Frances Braun in 1923, it is found primarily in the western United States, including California, Oregon, and Washington.  The moth is small, measuring around 9-11 millimeters in wingspan, and is characterized by its distinctive yellowish-brown wings with dark brown markings. Its larvae feed exclusively on *Stipa pulchra*, contributing to the plant's ecology.
George W. Owings III: George W. Owings III (1918-1991) was a prominent American architect who made significant contributions to the development of modern architecture. Owings was a founding partner of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill (SOM), one of the world's largest and most influential architectural firms. He played a key role in designing iconic structures such as the Lever House (1952) in New York City and the United States Air Force Academy (1954) in Colorado Springs. Owings, known for his commitment to collaboration and innovation, was a leading figure in the international style, emphasizing functionality, simplicity, and the use of new materials in his designs.
Eucalyptus amplifolia: *Eucalyptus amplifolia*, commonly known as the **broad-leaved red gum**, is a large, fast-growing eucalyptus tree native to eastern Australia. It is valued for its strong, durable timber, which has been used in construction, furniture making, and railway sleepers. The species is also a popular choice for reforestation and landscaping due to its tolerance to drought and poor soils. Notable botanist Ferdinand von Mueller first described *E. amplifolia* in 1855, and it has since been widely planted throughout the world, particularly in South Africa and California. Its distinctive features include its broad, leathery leaves and smooth, grey bark that sheds in strips, revealing a reddish-brown layer beneath.
Australia at the 2009 World Aquatics Cha: Australia achieved a strong performance at the 2009 World Aquatics Championships in Rome, Italy, securing a total of 14 medals, including 3 gold, 6 silver, and 5 bronze. Notably, the team excelled in swimming, with standout performances from Leisel Jones, who won gold in the 100-meter breaststroke, and Stephanie Rice, who claimed gold in the 200-meter individual medley and silver in the 400-meter individual medley. Other noteworthy contributions came from Eamon Sullivan, who took silver in the 50-meter freestyle, and the men's 4x100-meter freestyle relay team, who secured bronze. Australia's strong showing in Rome highlighted its enduring presence as a powerhouse in the world of swimming.
Cold War Liberation: The Soviet Union an: "Cold War Liberation: The Soviet Union and the Collapse of the Portuguese Empire in Africa, 1961–1975" explores the complex interplay between the Cold War and the decolonization of Portugal's African territories. From 1961 onwards, Portugal's colonial wars in Angola, Mozambique, and Guinea-Bissau gained international attention, with the Soviet Union actively supporting independence movements through military aid, training, and propaganda. The Soviet Union, seeking to expand its influence in the developing world and weaken Western influence, capitalized on Portugal's struggles and exploited the international pressure generated by the anti-colonial movement. This period witnessed a significant shift in power dynamics, ultimately leading to the collapse of the Portuguese Empire in Africa by 1975, marking a pivotal moment in both Cold War history and the decolonization process.
Berkenbr\u00fcck: Berkenbrück is a municipality in the Oder-Spree district of Brandenburg, Germany, located southeast of Berlin. Its history dates back to the 13th century, when it was first mentioned as "Berkenbruke." The village was significantly damaged during World War II but has since rebuilt and developed into a quiet rural community. Berkenbrück is known for its scenic landscapes and its proximity to the Spreewald, a unique biosphere reserve renowned for its canals and traditional boat transport. Today, the town is popular among nature enthusiasts and serves as a gateway to the region's natural beauty.
McMinnville Municipal Airport: McMinnville Municipal Airport (MMO) is a public use airport located two miles south of McMinnville, in Yamhill County, Oregon.  Opened in 1941, the airport served as a training facility for the United States Army Air Forces during World War II. It is currently owned and operated by the City of McMinnville and serves as a general aviation facility. MMO offers a variety of services, including aircraft maintenance, flight instruction, and charter flights. The airport also hosts several annual events, including the McMinnville Airshow and the Oregon International Air Races.
AutoGyro Calidus: The AutoGyro Calidus is a two-seat, single-engine, ultralight helicopter designed and manufactured by AutoGyro in Germany. It was introduced in 2007 and features a unique, open-air cockpit design with a side-by-side seating arrangement. The Calidus is powered by a Rotax 912 engine, known for its reliability and fuel efficiency. The helicopter is known for its versatility, being suitable for a wide range of applications, including recreational flying, flight training, and aerial photography.  Its innovative design and user-friendly operation have contributed to its popularity in the ultralight helicopter market.
Heidi Stroh: Heidi Stroh is a prominent figure in the field of contemporary art, known for her innovative mixed-media sculptures and installations.  Born in Germany in 1968, Stroh's work often explores themes of memory, identity, and the human condition. She has exhibited extensively in galleries and museums worldwide, including the Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo and the Tate Modern in London.  Stroh's distinct artistic style combines found objects, textiles, and digital media, resulting in thought-provoking and visually captivating pieces that invite viewers to engage with complex social and cultural issues.
Andy (2001 album): "Andy" is the debut studio album by American singer-songwriter Andy Grammer, released on October 2, 2001, by his own independent label, AndyGrammer Music. The album, which was recorded in New York City and Los Angeles, features a blend of pop, rock, and folk influences. Although it garnered little commercial success, "Andy" served as a crucial stepping stone for Grammer's musical journey. It showcased his early songwriting abilities and allowed him to establish himself as an independent artist, setting the stage for his future mainstream success with albums like "Magazines or Novels" (2011) and "Magazines or Novels (Deluxe Edition)" (2012).
Outrem\u00e9court: Outremécourt is a commune in the Meuse department in northeastern France. Located in the Lorraine region, the village is situated in the Côtes de Meuse, a rolling landscape known for its vineyards. The origins of Outremécourt can be traced back to the 12th century, with the commune gaining significance during the 16th century due to its involvement in the French Wars of Religion. Notable features include the Saint-Martin church, built in the 18th century, and the remnants of a 13th-century castle.  The village boasts a rich history, evidenced by archaeological discoveries dating back to Roman times, and remains a charming destination for those seeking rural tranquility.
South Park Lofts: South Park Lofts is a historic residential building located in downtown Los Angeles, California. Constructed in 1925, the building originally housed the Pacific Electric Railway headquarters and later became a manufacturing facility. In the 1990s, it was converted into luxury lofts, preserving many of its original architectural features, including exposed brick and steel beams. The building's distinctive design, with its massive arched windows and high ceilings, has become a landmark in the South Park neighborhood. Today, South Park Lofts is a popular destination for those seeking a unique and historic living experience in the heart of Los Angeles.
Treaty of Madrid (1801): The Treaty of Madrid, signed on March 21, 1801, was a peace treaty that officially ended the War of the Second Coalition. Negotiated between France and Spain, the treaty saw the Spanish monarchy recognize the French Republic and cede the island of Trinidad to Britain. In return, France ceded the territory of Louisiana to Spain, effectively restoring the pre-1762 territorial arrangement in the region. The treaty, although significant for its territorial adjustments, also marked a crucial step in the consolidation of French power under Napoleon Bonaparte, who had recently emerged as First Consul.
No More Mr. Nice Guy (Steve Wariner albu: "No More Mr. Nice Guy" is a studio album by American country music artist Steve Wariner, released in 1989 on the MCA Nashville label. The album was a commercial success, reaching number 2 on the Billboard Top Country Albums chart and producing three number-one singles on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart: "The Weekend" (1989), "I've Got Dreams To Remember" (1989), and "Love Has Got a Hold on You" (1990). The album's title track, a cover of the song by the group The Headliners, also achieved significant chart success, reaching number 3 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart. "No More Mr. Nice Guy" marked a significant period in Wariner's career, showcasing his growth as a vocalist and songwriter.
John Seward Johnson III: John Seward Johnson III (1930–2015) was an American sculptor and philanthropist known for his large-scale, whimsical sculptures known as "The Grounds for Sculpture," a public art museum in Hamilton, New Jersey. Johnson began his artistic career as a painter and printmaker but later turned to sculpture, primarily working with bronze and fiberglass. He founded the Grounds for Sculpture in 1992, transforming a former industrial site into a sprawling outdoor museum showcasing his own works and those of other artists. His enduring legacy is the creation of a unique artistic space that combines art, nature, and community.
Bull Moose Music: Bull Moose Music is a record store chain based in Portland, Maine, founded in 1987 by Bryce and Brett Chilcott.  Known for its extensive selection of new and used vinyl, CDs, and music-related merchandise, Bull Moose has grown from a single store to a regional chain with locations in Maine, New Hampshire, and Massachusetts. The store has become a cultural hub in its communities, hosting in-store performances, DJ sets, and special events, fostering a vibrant music scene and community engagement. Bull Moose's focus on providing a curated and personalized shopping experience, along with its dedication to supporting local artists, has earned it a loyal following among music enthusiasts.
Loire-Atlantique's 4th constituency: The 4th constituency of Loire-Atlantique is one of the 11 electoral districts that elect members to the National Assembly of France. Located in the Pays de la Loire region, the constituency covers the western part of Nantes and several surrounding communes. It was created in 1986, and its current boundaries were established after the 2010 redistricting. The constituency has historically been a stronghold for the Socialist Party, with its current representative being Johanna Rolland, who was first elected in 2017.
Lagonda 3-Litre: The Lagonda 3-Litre was a luxury car produced by the British manufacturer Lagonda from 1927 to 1935. Designed by W. O. Bentley, who had previously created the iconic Bentley 3 Litre, the Lagonda 3-Litre was a cutting-edge vehicle for its time. Notably featuring a straight-six engine with overhead valves and a rigid chassis, it offered impressive performance and comfort. The car's success led to the development of several variants, including the sporty 'Supercharged' version and the luxurious 'Touring' model. The Lagonda 3-Litre established the company as a major player in the luxury car market and helped to shape the evolution of British automotive design.
Vert, Yvelines: Vert is a commune in the Yvelines department in the Île-de-France region of France. Located about 30 kilometers southwest of Paris, the commune is known for its picturesque countryside and historic landmarks. Vert is home to the Château de Vert, a 16th-century castle that was once owned by the French royal family. The commune also boasts several other notable architectural features, including the Church of Saint-Germain, built in the 12th century. Vert's peaceful environment and proximity to the French capital make it a popular destination for both tourists and residents.
Skullduggery (album): "Skullduggery" is the debut studio album by the American heavy metal band,  Death Angel, released in 1987.  It was recorded at Fantasy Studios in Berkeley, California, and produced by  Randy Burns, known for his work with Metallica and Megadeth.  "Skullduggery" showcases the band's aggressive thrash metal sound, featuring  fast tempos, intricate guitar riffs, and lyrics often dealing with social and political themes.  The album, which was  released on  Enigma Records, achieved cult status among thrash metal fans, solidifying Death Angel's place in the Bay Area thrash scene.
Plumbing Trades Union: The Plumbing Trades Union (PTU) is a labor organization representing plumbers, pipefitters, and other related trades in the United States. Founded in 1889 as the United Association of Journeymen Plumbers, Gas Fitters, Steam Fitters and Steam Fitters Helpers of the United States and Canada, the PTU has a long history of advocating for workers' rights and safety standards in the plumbing industry.  Notable figures associated with the PTU include John J. Sweeney, who served as the organization's president from 1977 to 1995, and Martin J. Maddaloni, who served as president from 1995 to 2001. The PTU has played a significant role in shaping labor relations and safety practices within the plumbing industry, and it continues to advocate for its members' interests through collective bargaining and political activism.
Roborough, South Hams: Roborough is a village and civil parish in the South Hams district of Devon, England. Situated on the southern edge of Dartmoor National Park, Roborough is known for its picturesque setting and strong connection to the local landscape. The village boasts a rich history, with evidence of human settlement dating back to the Bronze Age. Notable features include the historic Roborough Down, a site of ancient settlements and prehistoric burial mounds, and the Roborough Manor, a historic house with a fascinating past. The village is a popular destination for hikers and nature enthusiasts, offering access to stunning views and peaceful walks across the rolling hills.
Cautious Hero: The Hero Is Overpowered b: "Cautious Hero: The Hero Is Overpowered but Overly Cautious" is a Japanese light novel series written by  Light Tuchihi and illustrated by Saeki. The story follows Seiya Ryuguin, a powerful hero tasked with saving a world from a demon lord, but his extreme caution leads to him becoming incredibly strong, while also making him excessively paranoid and preparing for every possible scenario. The series was adapted into a popular anime television series in 2019, known for its comedic portrayal of a hero who is overpowered but also extremely cautious, leading to numerous humorous situations. The light novel and anime have garnered a dedicated fanbase, with the series praised for its unique premise, engaging characters, and its blend of action and humor.
Craven Heifer: The "Craven Heifer" is a historic inn located in the village of Appletreewick, Yorkshire, England. The inn, which dates back to the 17th century, is notable for its distinctive half-timbered structure and its prominent position on the main road between Skipton and Pateley Bridge. The Craven Heifer has a long and rich history, having served as a popular stop for travelers and locals for centuries. It is said to have been a favorite haunt of the notorious highwayman Dick Turpin, and its name is believed to have originated from the practice of livestock being driven through the area. Today, the inn continues to be a popular destination, known for its traditional pub atmosphere, its extensive menu, and its picturesque setting.
Boiling Springs State Park: Boiling Springs State Park, located in the U.S. state of Ohio, is a popular recreation area known for its unique geological features. The park features a series of natural springs that have a constant temperature of 72 degrees Fahrenheit, even in the coldest weather. These springs are believed to be remnants of an ancient underground river system and contribute to the formation of the park's scenic waterfalls and lush vegetation. The park is also home to various hiking trails, a campground, and a historic grist mill dating back to the 19th century, offering opportunities for outdoor enthusiasts and history buffs alike.
Bern, Wisconsin: Bern, Wisconsin, is a town located in Green Lake County, Wisconsin, United States. Founded in 1852, the town derives its name from the Swiss capital, Bern, as many early settlers were of Swiss heritage.  Bern is known for its picturesque countryside and its role as a significant agricultural center. Notable local figures include Henry and Louise Schroeder, who built a renowned mill that remains a prominent landmark today. The town boasts a rich history, including a vibrant German heritage reflected in its architecture and traditions.
Jos\u00e9 Hern\u00e1ndez (Buenos Aires U: José Hernández was a prominent figure in the development of the Buenos Aires Underground, serving as its first General Manager from 1913 to 1916. He oversaw the construction and opening of the first line, known as the "Línea A," which began operating in 1913. Hernández, a visionary engineer and administrator, played a crucial role in establishing the foundations for the modern-day subway system in Buenos Aires, laying the groundwork for its future expansion. His contributions to the city's infrastructure and transportation network were widely recognized, solidifying his legacy as a key figure in the history of the Buenos Aires Underground.
James Carew (cricketer): James Carew was a prominent English cricketer who played for Gloucestershire and the England national team in the early 20th century. He was known for his exceptional batting skills, particularly his powerful hitting and ability to score quickly. Carew made his debut for Gloucestershire in 1906 and went on to play for England between 1910 and 1914, representing his country in 12 Test matches. He was a key member of the Gloucestershire team that dominated the County Championship in the 1910s, scoring over 15,000 runs for the county. Carew's career was tragically cut short due to World War I, during which he served in the Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve.
Mirza Ba\u0161i\u0107: Mirza Bašić (born 1969) is a Bosnian-American artist known for his contemporary Islamic calligraphy and innovative interpretations of traditional Islamic art.  Born in Sarajevo, Bosnia, Bašić immigrated to the United States in 1992, where he has since gained recognition for his distinctive style that blends traditional Islamic calligraphic techniques with modern aesthetics.  He often uses vibrant colors and unconventional materials like recycled metal and found objects, challenging conventional notions of Islamic art.  Bašić's work has been exhibited internationally and is featured in major collections including the Museum of Islamic Art in Doha, Qatar.  His artistic contributions have played a significant role in fostering greater understanding and appreciation of Islamic art within contemporary art discourse.
Herbertingen\u2013Isny railway: The Herbertingen–Isny railway is a 28.8-kilometer (17.9 mi) long, single-track, non-electrified railway line in the German state of Baden-Württemberg. Opened in 1899, the line connects the town of Herbertingen on the Ulm–Friedrichshafen railway with Isny im Allgäu. The line is mainly used for regional passenger transport, operated by the regional transport company, DB Regio. Notable features include the 1,000-meter (3,300 ft) long tunnel through the Herbertinger Berg mountain and the scenic route through the rolling hills of the Allgäu region.
Sysen Dam: The Sysen Dam is a gravity dam located on the Sysen River in the Norwegian municipality of Nord-Aurdal, Oppland county. Construction on the dam began in 1964 and was completed in 1967. The 50-meter-tall dam serves as a vital source of hydroelectric power generation, generating an estimated 150 GWh annually. Its reservoir, known as Sysen Lake, is a popular destination for fishing and recreational activities. The dam's construction significantly impacted the surrounding environment, requiring the relocation of several farms and the construction of a new road to access the reservoir.
Elena Terekhova: Elena Terekhova (born 1944) is a prominent Soviet and Russian actress known for her roles in films such as "The Adventures of Buratino" (1975) and "The Dawns Here Are Quiet" (1972). She graduated from the Moscow Art Theatre School in 1967 and made her film debut in 1966. Throughout her career, Terekhova received numerous accolades, including the prestigious USSR State Prize in 1977 for her performance in "The Dawns Here Are Quiet," which also earned her international recognition. Her performances are characterized by their elegance and emotional depth, making her one of the most celebrated actresses of her generation.
Daju languages: Daju languages are a group of Afro-Asiatic languages spoken primarily in Chad and Sudan. This language family is believed to be part of the Central Sudanic branch of the Afro-Asiatic language family, which also includes the Nilo-Saharan and Kordofanian language families. The Daju languages are spoken by various groups, including the Daju, Fur, and Masalit peoples, and are characterized by their complex sound systems and tonal features. Notable Daju languages include Fur, which is spoken in Sudan, and Maba, which is spoken in Chad. While some Daju languages are well-documented, others remain understudied and face threats of endangerment due to the influence of larger languages such as Arabic.
Krasnoznamensk, Moscow Oblast: Krasnoznamensk is a closed administrative-territorial entity (ZATO) located in Moscow Oblast, Russia. Established in 1951 as a military town, it was initially known as "Town #10" and later renamed in honor of the Red Banner of the Soviet Union. Krasnoznamensk is home to the "Voenny Gorodok" (Military Town) and is a significant center for military research and development, particularly in the fields of space technology and missile defense. Notably, the city houses the Research and Testing Space Center, which played a key role in the development of the Soviet space program, and is currently a major contributor to the Russian space industry.
Mazawattee Tea Company: Mazawattee Tea Company was a British tea importer and blender founded in 1887 by Charles Edward Paget. The company quickly gained popularity for its high-quality blends and distinctive packaging featuring a "Moorish maiden" logo. Mazawattee's success was attributed to its innovative marketing strategies, including the use of advertising slogans, such as "Mazawattee: the tea with the taste that's different." Despite its initial success, the company faced competition from larger tea companies and went into decline in the mid-20th century. The brand name "Mazawattee" survives today, though it is now owned by a different company.
Bergslagsbanans station: "Bergslagsbanans station" refers to any of the numerous train stations that served the Bergslagsbanan, a railway line in Sweden.  The line, opened in stages between 1871 and 1902, was crucial to the industrial development of the Bergslagen region, connecting mines, factories, and cities. The stations, designed in various styles reflecting the era of construction, provided essential transportation infrastructure for the region, facilitating the movement of goods and people. Notable stations include the Art Nouveau-inspired Fagersta station and the historic, timber-built station in Ludvika.  Today, many of these stations remain as landmarks, some still in use by the modern Bergslagsbanan, now operated by Tåg i Bergslagen.
Jonathan Dayton: Jonathan Dayton (1760-1824) was an American lawyer, politician, and one of the Founding Fathers who served as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention of 1787. Representing New Jersey, he played a crucial role in the drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution, particularly in securing the support of his state. He later served as a U.S. Congressman and Senator. Dayton's influence on the nation's founding document and his later political career solidified his place as a key figure in early American history.
Transkei dwarf chameleon: The Transkei dwarf chameleon ( _Bradypodion transvaalense_) is a small chameleon species endemic to the Eastern Cape Province of South Africa.  This reptile, reaching a maximum length of only 11 cm, is characterized by its striking brown and orange coloration and a distinctive crest running along its back.  The Transkei dwarf chameleon primarily inhabits the Eastern Cape's Albany Thicket biome, where it feeds on insects and uses its long, prehensile tail for balance and climbing.  This species, first described in 1986, is considered Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) due to its relatively wide distribution.
Gustav Davidsson: Gustav Davidsson (1902-1980) was a Swedish mountaineer and author known for his pioneering ascents of high-altitude peaks in the Himalayas. In 1935, he became the first European to summit the 7,134-meter high peak of Nanda Devi in India, a feat accomplished alongside his climbing partner, Arne Borgström. Davidsson's remarkable climb made him a legend in the world of mountaineering, and he went on to publish several books detailing his adventures, including "Nanda Devi: A First Ascent" (1936). His contributions to mountaineering and his detailed accounts of his expeditions continue to inspire climbers today.
Ksenia Sitnik: Ksenia Sitnik is a Belarusian singer and actress, best known for her victory in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2005 at the age of ten. She represented Belarus with the song "My vmeste," becoming the first ever winner of the contest and propelling her to stardom in Belarus and beyond. After winning, Sitnik continued to pursue a career in music, releasing several albums and performing at various events. She also branched out into acting, appearing in films and television shows. Her success in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest solidified her as a prominent figure in Belarusian entertainment and highlighted her musical talent at a young age.
Uster: Uster is a town and municipality in the canton of Zürich, Switzerland. Located in the Glatt Valley, it is situated about 20 kilometers northeast of the city of Zurich. Uster is known for its textile industry, which dates back to the 18th century and was particularly significant in the 19th and early 20th centuries. The town has a rich cultural heritage and hosts various events, including the Uster City Festival and the Uster Market. Notable landmarks include the Uster Castle, a 13th-century castle that was later rebuilt in the 18th century, and the Uster Church, a 13th-century church that is considered one of the oldest in the canton.
C.V.M. Tomis Constan\u021ba: C.V.M. Tomis Constanța is a Romanian professional rugby union club based in Constanța, Romania. Founded in 1957, the club has a rich history, having competed in the Romanian Rugby Championship and various European competitions. Known for their strong home support and passionate fanbase, Tomis Constanța has consistently been a force in Romanian rugby. The club has produced numerous talented players who have represented Romania at the international level, including Marius Tincu and Florin Vlaicu. C.V.M. Tomis Constanța continues to play a significant role in promoting rugby in the Constanța region and throughout Romania.
Sonny Side Up: "Sonny Side Up" is a 1968 American comedy film directed by Sidney Poitier, marking his directorial debut.  The film follows the story of Sonny, a young African American man who struggles to find his place in the world while navigating the complexities of love, family, and racial prejudice in 1960s New York City. Starring Sidney Poitier himself alongside Bill Cosby, Diana Sands, and Lou Gossett Jr., "Sonny Side Up" explores themes of social change and identity, offering a glimpse into the lived experiences of African Americans during a pivotal period in American history. The film's themes of hope and resilience resonated with audiences and contributed to the growing conversation about race and representation in American cinema.
Lake Ha! Ha!: "Lake Ha! Ha!" is a picturesque lake located in the Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean region of Quebec, Canada. Known for its dramatic natural beauty and its unique name, the lake is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts. The name, believed to originate from the sound of a waterfall echoing through the valley, has been recorded in historical documents dating back to the 18th century. The lake is part of a larger system of waterways, including the Saguenay River and Lac Saint-Jean, and is notable for its numerous islands and inlets, offering diverse opportunities for fishing, canoeing, and wildlife viewing.
Gwyn Martin: Gwyn Martin (1919–2004) was a prominent Australian historian and academic known for his contributions to the study of Australian colonial history, particularly in the fields of Victorian history and the convict system. His work focused on the social and economic structures of colonial Australia, particularly in relation to the development of penal colonies. Martin's most influential book, "The Transportation System: A History of Penal Convictism in New South Wales, Tasmania, Western Australia, and Norfolk Island" (1975), remains a definitive text on the topic. His research and writing significantly advanced the understanding of Australian convict history, and he held prominent positions at Monash University and the University of Melbourne.
Dunedin Writers & Readers Festival: The Dunedin Writers & Readers Festival is an annual literary festival held in Dunedin, New Zealand. Founded in 1989, it has become one of the largest and most respected literary events in the Southern Hemisphere. The festival features a diverse range of events, including readings, workshops, panel discussions, and book launches, showcasing both established and emerging writers from New Zealand and around the world. Notable guests have included authors like Margaret Atwood, Salman Rushdie, and Ian McEwan, highlighting the festival's commitment to bringing world-class literature to Dunedin.
Parsurameswara Temple: The Parsurameswara Temple, a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, is located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India. Built in the 7th century CE during the reign of the Sailodbhava dynasty, the temple is a prime example of early Kalinga architecture. It features a unique combination of Nagara and Dravidian styles, exemplified by its pyramidal spire (shikhara) and elaborate carvings. The temple is renowned for its exquisite sculptures depicting scenes from Hindu mythology and its intricate ornamentation, reflecting the high artistic standards of the era.
Allan McDonald (New Zealand politician): Allan McDonald was a prominent New Zealand politician who served as the Minister of Health from 1984 to 1987. He was a member of the Labour Party and represented the Hamilton East electorate in Parliament from 1978 to 1990.  McDonald was a key figure in the implementation of the landmark 1984 Social Security Act, which introduced significant changes to the New Zealand social welfare system. His tenure as Health Minister was marked by the introduction of the National Health Index, a system aimed at improving access to healthcare.  McDonald was known for his commitment to social justice and his advocacy for the rights of the less fortunate.
Henry County, Alabama: Henry County, Alabama, is a county located in the southeastern part of the state, bordering Georgia. Established in 1819 and named after Patrick Henry, a prominent figure in the American Revolution, the county is known for its agricultural heritage, particularly in cotton production.  The county seat is Abbeville, a town rich in history and notable for its role in the Civil War.  Henry County is also home to the historic Fort Gaines, a former Confederate fort that played a significant role in the defense of Mobile Bay during the war.
Eremophila glabra: *Eremophila glabra*, commonly known as the **smooth emu bush**, is a species of flowering plant in the figwort family, native to Australia.  It is a small to medium-sized shrub, typically reaching heights of 1 to 3 meters, with smooth, grey-green leaves and showy, tubular flowers ranging from purple to pink.  This plant is particularly adapted to arid environments and is a significant source of nectar for pollinators like birds and insects.  It is also considered to be a valuable source of essential oils, particularly those with antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties, making it of interest to both traditional and modern medicine.
Doboj East: Doboj East is a municipality located in the Republika Srpska entity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Situated in the Semberija region, it borders the municipalities of Doboj, Modriča, and Bijeljina. The municipality was formed in 1992 during the Bosnian War, encompassing territories formerly belonging to the municipality of Doboj. Notable features of Doboj East include the historical village of Osječani and the agricultural land that contributes significantly to the region's economy. The municipality's population is primarily Bosnian Serb, with a smaller Bosniak minority.
What a Horrible Night to Have a Curse: "What a Horrible Night to Have a Curse" is the 23rd episode of the American animated television series *The Owl House*, which premiered on Disney Channel on May 21, 2023. The episode marks the series' penultimate episode and sees Luz Noceda, a human girl who has been trapped in the Boiling Isles, facing off against Emperor Belos, the tyrannical ruler of the demon realm. It features the first major confrontation between Luz and Belos, showcasing the latter's true form and power while Luz and her friends attempt to stop him from enacting his ultimate plan. The episode is notable for its emotionally charged climax and its introduction of new lore and characters, including a mysterious figure known as "The Collector."
Connie Sellecca: Connie Sellecca is an American actress, producer, and former model, known for her roles in popular television series of the 1980s. She rose to prominence as the star of the medical drama "Hotel," which aired from 1983 to 1988. Sellecca's acting career also included roles in shows like "The Greatest American Hero" and "The Fall Guy." Beyond acting, she has been a successful producer, working on projects like "The Nanny" and "The Division." Sellecca's long career in entertainment has earned her both critical acclaim and recognition from the industry.
No Shade in the Shadow of the Cross: "No Shade in the Shadow of the Cross" is a 1995 novel by American author John Grisham, focusing on the complexities of the legal system and its impact on a small town. The story revolves around a wrongful conviction case that deeply affects the lives of several characters, including a dedicated attorney, a falsely accused man, and a grieving family. Grisham's novel highlights the struggles for justice and the inherent biases within the legal system, offering a gripping narrative that explores themes of innocence, guilt, and the pursuit of truth. The book's success solidified Grisham's position as a prominent legal thriller author and further cemented his reputation for creating suspenseful narratives centered around courtroom dramas.
Tufuga Fatu: Tufuga Fatu (born January 1, 1964), better known by his ring name Umaga, was a Samoan professional wrestler.  He was notable for his imposing physique and dominant wrestling style, winning numerous championships in the World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) from 2002 to 2009.  Fatu, who was trained by his uncle Afa Anoaʻi, started his career in the early 1990s, wrestling for organizations like World Championship Wrestling (WCW) before joining WWE in 2002.  His signature moves included the Samoan Spike and the Running Spear, making him a formidable force in the ring.  After his retirement from wrestling, Fatu unfortunately passed away in December 2009.
Akashic records: The Akashic Records, also known as the Book of Life, are a purported collection of all events, thoughts, and emotions that have ever occurred in the universe. This concept, rooted in ancient Hindu and Buddhist philosophies, suggests that the records are a universal database accessible through spiritual means.  Advocates believe that these records contain the history of every soul and can be accessed through meditation, trance, or other spiritual practices. While the concept has been popularized in New Age spirituality, there is no scientific evidence to support its existence, and it remains a matter of faith and personal belief. The Akashic Records have been popularized in the works of authors like Edgar Cayce and have inspired various spiritual practices and belief systems.
1909 Holy Trinity Hilltoppers football t: The 1909 Holy Trinity Hilltoppers football team represented Holy Trinity High School in New York City during the 1909 college football season.  The team was coached by Joseph "Joe" Hartigan, who led the Hilltoppers to a 4-2-1 record, including a victory over the undefeated New York University Violets.  The Hilltoppers were known for their strong defense and the leadership of quarterback James "Jim" O'Brien.  The 1909 team is considered a significant milestone in the history of Holy Trinity High School athletics, as it marked the first time the school fielded a football team that competed against major college programs.
Lathiceridae: Lathiceridae is a family of small, predatory sea snails, also known as "false limpets," belonging to the order Neogastropoda. They are characterized by their distinctive, low, conical shell, often with a flared aperture. These marine gastropods are found primarily in the Indo-Pacific region, with some species inhabiting the Atlantic Ocean. Notably, the family contains a single genus, *Lathicerus*, first described by the French malacologist, Jean-Baptiste Lamarck, in 1812.  While their taxonomic classification has been debated over the years, they are currently considered a distinct family within the Neogastropoda, based on their unique morphological and anatomical features.
2010 AAA Texas 500: The 2010 AAA Texas 500 was a NASCAR Sprint Cup Series race held on November 7, 2010, at Texas Motor Speedway in Fort Worth, Texas. The race was the 34th and final race of the 2010 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series season.  It was won by Jimmie Johnson, who clinched his fifth consecutive Sprint Cup Series championship by winning the race. The race was notable for its dramatic finish, with Johnson overtaking Denny Hamlin on the final lap after Hamlin had led for much of the race.  The event also saw several lead changes, with drivers like Carl Edwards, Jeff Gordon, and Kyle Busch also leading laps.
Raga Mala (book): "Raga Mala" is a 16th-century Sanskrit treatise on Indian classical music, authored by the renowned musician and scholar, Ahobalā. The text, composed in verse form, provides a comprehensive analysis of the theoretical framework of ragas, the melodic modes that form the foundation of Indian classical music. Ahobalā's "Raga Mala" is considered a pivotal work in the history of Indian music theory, particularly for its detailed explanations of raga structures, ornamentation techniques, and the relationship between musical elements and emotional expression. It has served as a foundational text for generations of musicians and scholars, contributing significantly to the understanding and practice of Indian classical music.
Bullet to Beijing: "Bullet to Beijing" is a 1998 action thriller film directed by  Roger Donaldson, starring  Chow Yun-fat and Michelle Yeoh.  The film follows the story of a Hong Kong police officer,  Ryan Walker (Chow Yun-fat), who is tasked with escorting a  Chinese scientist,  Dr. Helen Lin (Michelle Yeoh), to Beijing for a vital medical conference.  Their journey is jeopardized by a  ruthless assassin (played by  Michael Biehn) who seeks to kill the scientist, resulting in a high-octane chase through multiple countries and a tense climax in  Beijing. The film features a blend of  action sequences,  political intrigue, and a touch of romance, showcasing the talents of  Chow Yun-fat and Michelle Yeoh as skilled action stars.
NASUWT: NASUWT, or the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, is a trade union representing teachers and support staff in the United Kingdom. Founded in 1889 as the National Union of Teachers (NUT) and incorporating the Schoolmasters' Association in 1919, the union changed its name to NASUWT in 1989. The NASUWT is the second largest teaching union in the UK and is known for its strong advocacy for teachers' rights and working conditions, including promoting fair pay, professional development, and educational policies that benefit students. Notable figures associated with the NASUWT include former general secretaries Christine Blower and Chris Keates.
John Greenleaf Whittier House: The John Greenleaf Whittier House, located in Haverhill, Massachusetts, is a historic house museum dedicated to the life and work of the renowned American poet John Greenleaf Whittier. Built in 1810, the house served as Whittier's childhood home and later became a literary landmark, attracting visitors from around the world. The house, designated a National Historic Landmark in 1963, features original furnishings, personal belongings, and a collection of Whittier's manuscripts and letters. The museum also hosts educational programs and events related to Whittier's life and legacy.
Myron Nettinga: Myron Nettinga (1922-2005) was a Dutch-born American artist and educator renowned for his contributions to the art of printmaking. He was a professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison from 1954 to 1987, where he established a renowned printmaking program, fostering a new generation of artists. Nettinga was known for his mastery of various printmaking techniques, particularly woodcuts, which he used to create expressive and evocative works often depicting rural landscapes and figures. He held numerous solo exhibitions throughout his career and was a recipient of the Wisconsin Arts Board's Governor's Award for the Arts in 1987.
Rainbow Interchange: The Rainbow Interchange, officially known as the "Spaghetti Junction," is a complex highway interchange located in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Constructed in 1958, it is renowned for its distinctive six-level configuration and its intricate network of ramps connecting five major highways.  The interchange was designed by the renowned engineer Michael Baker Jr., and its construction marked a significant milestone in highway engineering. Today, the Rainbow Interchange remains a vital transportation hub, handling a massive volume of traffic daily and serving as a prominent symbol of Pittsburgh's infrastructure.
Paolo La Rosa: Paolo La Rosa is an Italian-American actor, known for his work in both film and television. Born in Brooklyn, New York, La Rosa began his acting career in the 1990s, appearing in various TV shows and movies. He has had notable roles in popular television series like "Law & Order" and "The Sopranos." La Rosa has also showcased his talent in films such as "The Godfather: Part III" and "A Bronx Tale," where he portrayed the iconic role of "Calogero" in his younger years. His versatility and memorable performances have cemented his position as a respected figure in the entertainment industry.
Micrite: Micrite is a type of limestone characterized by its fine-grained, mud-sized crystals of calcite, typically less than 4 micrometers in diameter. It forms in low-energy environments where fine carbonate sediment accumulates, such as quiet lagoons or the deep ocean.  Micrite is often found intermixed with larger grains, like fossils or ooids, creating mixed carbonate rocks. Its fine grain size makes it difficult to identify individual crystals with the naked eye, but it can be easily distinguished under a microscope.  The study of micrite is important for understanding the depositional environments of sedimentary rocks and provides insights into ancient marine ecosystems.
Miguel Terceros: Miguel Terceros (born 1986) is a contemporary Argentine artist renowned for his innovative and impactful multimedia installations. He is known for blending traditional artistic techniques with modern technology, creating immersive experiences that often explore themes of memory, identity, and social commentary. Terceros' work has been exhibited internationally in prominent venues such as the Museo de Arte Moderno de Buenos Aires and the Venice Biennale. He has received significant recognition, including the prestigious Konex Award in 2020, solidifying his position as a leading figure in the contemporary art world.
Svatoslav (Brno-Country District): Svatoslav is a municipality and village located in the Brno-Country District of the South Moravian Region in the Czech Republic. The village is situated on the left bank of the Svratka River, approximately 10 kilometers north of Brno.  The first written record of Svatoslav dates back to 1348, and its history is marked by its agricultural past and a strong community spirit. The village is known for its picturesque location and is a popular destination for outdoor activities such as hiking and cycling.  Notable local landmarks include the Church of St. Wenceslaus, which was built in the 18th century, and the Svatoslav Chateau, which dates back to the 17th century.
Joliet Army Ammunition Plant: The Joliet Army Ammunition Plant, located near Joliet, Illinois, was a major munitions production facility during World War II. Established in 1941, the plant employed over 15,000 workers at its peak, producing a vast array of ammunition and explosives. After the war, the plant continued operations, primarily producing artillery ammunition and rockets, and was also briefly used during the Korean War and Vietnam War. Due to its strategic importance, the facility was placed under the control of the U.S. Army and later the Department of Defense.  The plant was officially closed in 1995 and has since been partially demolished, with a portion of the land now used for commercial and industrial development.
Evgeni Krasnopolski: Evgeni Krasnopolski (born 1957) is a prominent Soviet and Russian astronomer known for his significant contributions to the study of minor planets. His work has focused on the discovery and characterization of asteroids, including the discovery of several binary asteroid systems.  Krasnopolski is a member of the International Astronomical Union and has been a leading figure in the development of techniques for observing and analyzing asteroids. Notably, he has been involved in projects such as the Crimean Astrophysical Observatory and the Lowell Observatory.  His research has significantly advanced the understanding of the asteroid belt and the formation of the solar system.
College Street Historic District (Harrod: The College Street Historic District in Harrodsburg, Kentucky, is a nationally recognized historic district encompassing a significant portion of the city's central area. Established in 1982, the district showcases a collection of architecturally diverse buildings, primarily constructed between the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Notable features include the imposing Mercer County Courthouse, designed in the Romanesque Revival style by renowned architect, Frank L. Lockwood, and several residential structures reflecting popular Victorian and Queen Anne architectural trends. The district offers a tangible glimpse into Harrodsburg's rich history and development, serving as a reminder of the city's importance as a regional center during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Nazareth Area High School: Nazareth Area High School is a public high school located in Upper Nazareth Township, Pennsylvania, serving the Nazareth Area School District. Founded in 1964, the school replaced the former Nazareth High School and Palmer Township High School, consolidating the two into a single institution. The school has a long-standing tradition of academic excellence and offers a variety of extracurricular activities, including sports, music, and clubs. Notable alumni include professional athletes like Olympic volleyball player Nicole Fawcett and NFL player Ryan Howard.
Naknek River: The Naknek River is a major salmon-bearing river located in southwestern Alaska, flowing approximately 80 miles from its headwaters in the Aleutian Range to its mouth at Naknek Lake. The river is a vital ecosystem for numerous fish species, particularly sockeye salmon, which utilize the river for spawning. Historically, the area was inhabited by indigenous peoples, including the Alutiiq and Dena'ina, who relied heavily on the river's resources for subsistence. Today, the Naknek River is a popular destination for sport fishing and is managed by the Alaska Department of Fish and Game to ensure the sustainability of its salmon populations.
Lombok International Airport: Lombok International Airport (LOP), formerly known as Selaparang Airport, is the primary airport serving the island of Lombok, Indonesia. Located in the city of Praya, the airport underwent a major expansion and modernization in 2019, becoming a crucial gateway for tourists visiting Lombok's renowned beaches and natural attractions. The airport serves as a hub for several domestic airlines, connecting Lombok to major cities throughout Indonesia. Notably, the airport is also served by several international airlines, facilitating increased tourism to the island.
Castleholme Homestead: Castleholme Homestead, located in [Location], is a historic property with a rich history dating back to [Year]. The homestead was originally built by [Original Owner] and has seen various uses over the years, including [Examples: farming, a family residence, or a community gathering place]. Notably, Castleholme is known for its [Unique Features: Architectural style, historical significance, or notable inhabitants]. Kara\u0111or\u0111evo (Ba\u010dka Palank: Karađorđevo, located near the town of Bačka Palanka in Serbia, is a historic site renowned for its association with the Serbian Revolution. Established in 1805 by the Serbian revolutionary leader Karađorđe Petrović, the settlement served as a military base and administrative center during the struggle against Ottoman rule. The site is significant for its historical importance, hosting several key events during the Revolution, including the election of Karađorđe as Supreme Leader in 1807. Today, Karađorđevo remains a testament to the pivotal role it played in the Serbian fight for independence and features a museum dedicated to this period.
Mangalam Publications: Mangalam Publications is a prominent Indian media company known for its diverse portfolio of publications and digital platforms. Founded in 1974 by M. P. Veerendra Kumar, the company has been a major force in the Malayalam language media landscape. Its flagship publication, "Mangalam Weekly," remains one of the most widely read Malayalam magazines, covering news, politics, entertainment, and social issues. The company has expanded its reach with various other publications like "Mangalam Daily" and "Mangalam Online," along with radio and television ventures. Mangalam Publications has been recognized for its journalistic integrity and influence within the Kerala region.
Spotted jelly: "Spotted jelly" is a common name for various jellyfish species characterized by distinctive spots or patterns on their bell or tentacles. These species are found in different marine environments worldwide, and their specific characteristics can vary depending on the species. Some notable examples include the spotted jellyfish (Phyllorhiza punctata), which is a large, translucent jellyfish with brown spots, and the moon jelly (Aurelia aurita), which has four horseshoe-shaped gonads visible as distinct spots on its bell. Spotted jellies play an important role in marine ecosystems, acting as both predator and prey, but some species can also pose a sting hazard to humans.
Droupadi Murmu: Droupadi Murmu is the 15th and current President of India, assuming office in July 2022. She is the first tribal woman and second woman to hold the presidential post, signifying a significant milestone in India's political landscape. Murmu's journey from a teacher to the highest political office reflects her dedication to public service. Born in Odisha in 1958, she served as the Governor of Jharkhand (2015-2021) before her presidential election. Her presidency has been met with widespread acclaim, particularly among tribal communities who see her as a symbol of empowerment and inclusion.
Climate Change and Global Energy Securit: Climate change and global energy security are inextricably linked, as the transition to cleaner energy sources is crucial for mitigating the impacts of climate change while ensuring reliable and affordable energy supplies. The shift away from fossil fuels, which contribute significantly to greenhouse gas emissions, presents challenges and opportunities for energy security.  Efforts to address this complex issue include the development of renewable energy technologies, improvements in energy efficiency, and advancements in energy storage solutions. Key players in this field include international organizations like the International Energy Agency (IEA), national governments, and private sector companies working towards a sustainable energy future.
PGL Travel: PGL Travel is a British company specializing in residential adventure holidays for children and young people. Founded in 1957 as "Progressive Group Leadership," PGL offers a variety of activities, including climbing, canoeing, archery, and team-building exercises. The company operates over 20 centers across the United Kingdom, as well as locations in France, Spain, and the United States. PGL's mission is to provide a safe and fun environment for young people to develop new skills, build confidence, and create lasting memories. Notable figures associated with PGL include founder, John Hunt, and CEO, Andy Johnson.
Pucciniaceae: Pucciniaceae is a family of parasitic fungi within the order Pucciniales, commonly known as rust fungi. These fungi are obligate parasites, meaning they require a living host to complete their life cycle. The Pucciniaceae family encompasses a diverse range of species, many of which cause significant economic damage to crops, such as wheat rust, caused by *Puccinia graminis*.  The family is characterized by its complex life cycle involving multiple spore stages and often requiring two or more different host plants for completion.  Notable figures in the study of Pucciniaceae include the mycologist, Joseph Charles Arthur, who established a system for classifying rust fungi based on their complex life cycles.
Aplochiton: *Aplochiton* is a genus of freshwater fish belonging to the Galaxiidae family. These small, eel-like fish are native to the cool, clean waters of Tasmania and New Zealand, with some species also found in Chile. Notably, *Aplochiton* species are considered "living fossils" due to their ancient lineage, dating back to the Jurassic period. Their unique features include a distinctive lack of scales and a long, slender body adapted for life in fast-flowing streams and rivers. The genus *Aplochiton* is of significant ecological importance, playing a vital role in the freshwater ecosystems of their native regions.
Joy Plaza: Joy Plaza is a large shopping mall located in the heart of Quezon City, Philippines. Opened in 1996, the mall is renowned for its wide range of retail stores, dining options, and entertainment facilities. It has been a popular destination for Filipinos and tourists alike, attracting millions of visitors annually. Notably, the mall is home to a diverse selection of international and local brands, including department stores, fashion boutiques, electronics retailers, and supermarkets. Joy Plaza has also hosted numerous events, concerts, and exhibitions, making it a prominent cultural hub in the region.
Path of Democracy: "Path of Democracy" is a concept that describes the historical and ongoing journey of democratic principles and institutions around the world. It encompasses a diverse range of events, from the rise of ancient Greek democracy to modern democratic movements and transitions. This path is characterized by both progress and setbacks, marked by figures like Abraham Lincoln, Mahatma Gandhi, and Nelson Mandela who championed democratic ideals. The concept highlights the ongoing struggle for individual rights, freedom of expression, and fair representation, reminding us that democracy is a fragile and evolving system that requires constant vigilance and participation.
Hobson Block: The Hobson Block, located in the historic district of downtown San Francisco, is a landmark building recognized for its distinctive architectural style and historical significance. Originally constructed in 1853, the building served as a commercial hub during the city's rapid growth following the Gold Rush. The Hobson Block's eclectic design blends Victorian, Italianate, and Romanesque influences, showcasing a unique blend of architectural trends popular at the time. Notable figures associated with the building include William Hobson, a prominent businessman who played a crucial role in its development. Today, the Hobson Block stands as a testament to San Francisco's architectural heritage and serves as a reminder of the city's vibrant history.
The Last Rites of Joe May: "The Last Rites of Joe May" is a 1970 novel by American author William Gaddis. It follows the complex narrative of Oscar Crease, a young man grappling with the sudden death of his father, Joe May. The novel, known for its experimental style and dense prose, explores themes of family, loss, and the search for meaning in a rapidly changing world. Gaddis's work, often considered difficult but rewarding, utilizes complex interweaving storylines and a fragmented narrative structure to create a deeply insightful and ultimately poignant portrait of the human condition. While the novel was initially met with mixed reviews, it has since garnered critical acclaim as a major work of American postmodern literature.
All She Wants Is: "All She Wants Is" is a song by the British pop group Ace of Base, released in 1993 as the lead single from their debut album, "The Sign." The song achieved global success, reaching number one in numerous countries including the United Kingdom, Australia, and Germany. Its catchy melody, memorable lyrics, and upbeat tempo contributed to its popularity.  "All She Wants Is" featured the distinctive vocal harmonies of the band's members, particularly Linn Berggren, and was a defining track in the Swedish pop music scene of the 1990s. The song's success established Ace of Base as one of the most popular pop acts of the decade.
Skibbereen Town Hall: Skibbereen Town Hall is a prominent civic building located in the town of Skibbereen, County Cork, Ireland. Built in 1853, the hall was designed in the Italianate style by the architect William Henry Deane and serves as a testament to the town's prosperity during the mid-19th century. Notably, the building hosted a major public meeting in 1847, convened by the prominent Irish politician Daniel O'Connell, in response to the devastating famine that ravaged Ireland at the time. Today, the Skibbereen Town Hall stands as a landmark, reflecting the town's history and serving as a venue for various community events and cultural activities.
Phraya Anuman Rajadhon: Phraya Anuman Rajadhon (1889-1969) was a prominent Thai scholar and linguist, widely recognized as the "Father of Thai Linguistics." He made significant contributions to the study of Thai language and culture, notably through his work on etymology, lexicography, and folk traditions. Anuman compiled the first comprehensive Thai dictionary, "The Dictionary of the Royal Institute," which became a cornerstone of Thai lexicography. He also established the Thai Language Institute in 1943, which continues to be a vital resource for research and standardization of the Thai language. His extensive research and scholarship helped to solidify and preserve Thai cultural heritage, making him a revered figure in Thai intellectual history.
Spanish architecture: Spanish architecture encompasses a diverse range of styles and influences that have evolved over centuries, reflecting the country's rich history and cultural exchange. From the Romanesque and Moorish influences of the Middle Ages to the Renaissance and Baroque periods, Spanish architecture has been characterized by its use of ornate details, intricate facades, and a blend of religious and secular elements. Notable examples include the Alhambra in Granada, a masterpiece of Islamic architecture, and the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, a modernist masterpiece by Antoni Gaudí. Spanish architecture continues to evolve today, incorporating contemporary trends while maintaining its distinctive character.
2022 Pepperdine Waves men's volleyball t: The 2022 Pepperdine Waves men's volleyball team represented Pepperdine University in the 2022 NCAA Division I men's volleyball season. The Waves, coached by David  Hunt, finished the regular season with a 19–10 record, securing a spot in the NCAA Men's Volleyball Tournament. Led by standout players like Jaylen Jasper and Joe Grigsby, the Waves advanced to the NCAA semifinals where they were defeated by eventual national champions, UCLA.  The 2022 season marked the team's continued success in the highly competitive Mountain Pacific Sports Federation (MPSF) conference.
Olympus PEN E-PM2: The Olympus PEN E-PM2 is a mirrorless interchangeable-lens camera released in October 2012 as a successor to the Olympus PEN E-PM1. Notable features include a 16.1 MP Live MOS sensor, a 3-inch touchscreen LCD, and a built-in electronic viewfinder. The E-PM2 is designed for portability and ease of use, featuring a compact body and a variety of shooting modes suitable for both beginners and experienced photographers. Like other cameras in the Olympus PEN series, the E-PM2 is known for its attractive retro design and its ability to capture high-quality images and videos.
RAF Hawkinge: RAF Hawkinge, located in Kent, England, was a Royal Air Force station active during World War II. Established in 1916 as an airfield, it played a significant role in the defense of Great Britain during the war, hosting numerous fighter squadrons. Notable units stationed at Hawkinge included No. 11 Squadron and No. 74 Squadron, contributing to the Battle of Britain and other aerial operations. The station remained in use after the war, serving as a base for various RAF units and becoming a reserve airfield before being officially closed in 1959.
Forza Sempre: "Forza Sempre" is an Italian phrase meaning "Strength Always" and is commonly used as a rallying cry or motto, particularly within Italian sports and cultural contexts. It is often associated with the Italian football club, Inter Milan, where it serves as a chant amongst supporters. The phrase has gained wider recognition in popular culture, being used by other sports teams, individuals, and even as a brand name. "Forza Sempre" embodies a spirit of perseverance, determination, and unwavering support, highlighting the enduring power of unity and shared passion.
Intervale Street-Blue Hill Avenue Histor: The Intervale Street-Blue Hill Avenue Historic District, located in Boston, Massachusetts, encompasses a diverse collection of buildings that reflect the city's 19th and 20th-century development. Established in 1983, the district features a variety of architectural styles, including Victorian, Colonial Revival, and Queen Anne, showcasing the evolving tastes and construction methods of the time. It is notable for its diverse population and rich history, encompassing the neighborhood's role as a thriving commercial center and its connection to the city's African American community. The district is a testament to the enduring legacy of the area's growth and transformation, preserving a significant portion of Boston's architectural and cultural heritage.
Woodward\u2013Hoffmann rules: The Woodward–Hoffmann rules, developed in the mid-1960s by Robert Burns Woodward and Roald Hoffmann, are a set of principles that predict the stereochemistry and regiochemistry of pericyclic reactions. These rules, based on the conservation of orbital symmetry, revolutionized organic chemistry by providing a theoretical framework for understanding the course of complex reactions. Notably, the rules are used to predict the outcome of reactions like Diels-Alder cycloadditions, electrocyclic reactions, and sigmatropic rearrangements. For their groundbreaking work, Woodward and Hoffmann were awarded the 1981 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
Eva Hodanov\u00e1: Eva Hodanová (1920-2009) was a Czech painter and graphic artist known for her distinctive style, characterized by vibrant colors, playful compositions, and a focus on everyday life in Prague. Her work often featured motifs of animals, children, and the city's charming architecture. Hodanová began her artistic career in the 1940s, studying at the Academy of Fine Arts in Prague under influential Czech artists such as Josef Kaplický and Václav Špála. Her work was exhibited widely throughout her life, and she received recognition through numerous awards and exhibitions, securing her place as a significant figure in Czech art.
Coronaca, South Carolina: Coronaca is a town in Abbeville County, South Carolina, United States. It was incorporated in 1890 and is situated near the Savannah River. Notable features include the historic Coronaca Presbyterian Church, established in 1839, and the nearby Lake Russell, offering recreational opportunities. The town is known for its agricultural heritage, particularly cotton production, and has a rich history of community gatherings and festivals, such as the annual Coronaca Peach Festival.
